text:
Very nice indeed but admittedly not the best I have had. I used the nuts as they came in the pack, but next time I will whizz them up in the blender to chop them even finer. The layers didn't hold together quite as they should so next time I will make the syrup a little heavier - 235ml water to 235g sugar rather than 200g of sugar. Also next time I might add some lemon zest to the nut mixture and a little lemon juice in the syrup.

text:
I like this recipe, and am half Greek! I learnt from the authentic chef - my mother. However,if you are on a strict budget and enjoy treating your friends to this dessert more often  given the expense of honey I would change the following:  Replace orange juice and a little zest (no pulp) for the water and half the honey and 3/4 or less cup of sugar while making the syrup. No lemon zest in this case. It makes a thick enough syrup. My baklava never sits around long enough to get soggy.  It fools the mind and delights the senses. My diabetic friends can dose their insulin according to the number of slices they indulge in.  Enjoy

Display Name:
shelbycocking

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. I have tried to make baklava before with no success (I am not a genius in the kitchen though I try to be ; ) ).  I made this with no trouble at all.  I use pistachios and they really add flavor. I also layer and butter 6-8 sheets of phyllo between nut layers. Doing this really defines each layer and with the green of the pistachios it makes it really pretty. The only other thing I do is add about 1/8 cup of honey to the sauce. It kind of gives it some extra stickiness which I actually like. This is a wonderful recipe and really fun to play around with. It is actually simple enough for my 12 year old to do. I love working with phyllo (not sure why!). A trick I use if I can't work fast and it will dry out is to put a damp towel over it. When I say damp though, I mean barely wet! I just spray it once or twice with a spray bottle. That keeps it from getting too moit and sticking. My family loves this treat and they have me make it for them every holiday.

Hubby likes it drenched in syrup so I made a little extra syrup and drizzled more on top of his.

text:
Really yummy, and I got alot of people at the office asking me for the recipe! My boss wanted Middle Eastern food for a meeting- Got the food, but the place that I got it from doesn't have good baklava, so I made it myself.  The ONLY thing I would change on the recipe is that I didn't need to cut the sheets b/c they fit the size of the cookie sheets. I think it just depends on the brand you get. I measured the standard ones at the store, and they are alot shorter on both ends, so the directions that NEONWILLIE gave is probably correct.  I layered at least 8 sheets on the bottom, 2 first, butter, 2 more, butter, etc. Then 1/3 of the nuts, 2 more sheets, butter, 2 more sheets, 1/3 of the nuts, etc.  Using onlly 2-3 T. of nuts, you would end up w/ too many nuts at the end. Also, I doubled up the syrup, because I like mine sticky- and that is proportionate to what was called for on the recipe on the box.  On the phyllo dough box recipe, they added in 1/8 t. cloves- I did a sprinkle so I wouldn't deviate too far from this recipe, and it came out really good.  (Boss was happy!)

text:
I absolutely love this recipe. I'm making three batches for Christmas for the family. The only thing I did differently is I added one more phyllo sheet between layers of nuts. The nuts kept tearing the dough apart with only two layers, one more layer fixed it. Whatever you do, cut the baklava before pouring on the honey mixture. I had a completely stupid moment and didn't cut it on one batch. The center didn't get sweet, but that was my fault! I love this recipe so much, it's so relaxing for me to make. Just takes time and patience. Going to experiment with other nuts later, I've used pecans every time. And DON'T be stingy with the butter!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent. So delicious I had to make another one a few days after finishing the first one. I make the syrup first and let it cook while I assemble everything. The first time I had funny shaped little scraps of phyllo because of the way I trimmed the dough. I used them to piecemeal several layers and no one could tell the difference. The next time I trimmed the dough properly and had nice sheets for the baklava, which made things easier. The first time I used only 1/2 a cup of butter for the whole pan and baked at 350. It was browned and crispy. The second time, I baked at 325 and used the full 1 cup of butter. A few of the phyllo layers didn't seem cooked and the whole thing was not as crisp. I also tried using 1x the recipe for the syrup and 1.5 times as someone else suggested. It was too sweet with the extra syrup, but just right with the written amount. I will definitely be making this again! This recipe is not difficult, even though it does take time. I've found making a baklava to actually be quite therapeutic!
Thanks.

text:
I have been making this recipe for a few years now, and I have become famous for it. It's easy to put together, although a little messy and time consuming, although I manage 48 pieces out of one recipe. I have always poured the hot honey over the baklava, and found that it works well, although I am planning on trying it cooled next time. I have never 1 1/2 the honey, and find it's sweet enough, just like any I have bought in the stores. For any Canadians trying this recipe I suggest the President's Choice brand of phyllo (from superstore or Extra foods). I also add about 1/2 tsp of cinnamon to the honey and a couple of splashes of amaretto. This has become a Christmas tradition in my house.

text:
Okay so I made this today, and I am so glad I did. I could hardly wait for it to cool to try it. It is fantastic!! I took some over to my in-laws and they said it was the best they ever had. 
I took the advice of many, and made the syrup ahead of time. And made 50% more like suggested, but didn't use it all. I used a mix of walnuts, pistachios, and almonds and roasted them before chopping. I used my food processor to chop them up, and it was a perfect combo of finely chopped nuts with just a few chunks. The phyllo dough was surprisingly easy to work with. I kept the plastic wrap over it and a damp towel over the wrap. I only used slightly more butter than the recipe called for. I baked it at 325 for 50 minutes and poured the cooled sauce over it. Incredible!! I will most definitely make this again, and I am thinking of using Pam Butter flavor, and replace half the honey with half light corn syrup (I'm not huge on honey). All in all, fantastic recipe. Delectable!

userID:
1323013
Display Name:
CHERYLSKITCHEN
isPro:

1

146

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5986638.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
For what appears to be a complicated dessert, this is fairly easy to make.  My mother used to make this recipe all the time for my Egyptian stepdad. I make a few changes. I make the syrup first and cool it to poor on the hot Baklava. Watch the syrup; it will seem like its not boiling, then boil over quickly. It took me an hour to clean my stovetop since I did it twice! I don't cover the Phyllo dough, as I'm pretty quick and make sure to not brush too much butter; you should not need more than what the recipe calls for. Just use quick brief dabs and strokes of butter and don't worry about covering all of the sheet; it will bunch some, but don't worry about it too much. I use a heaping tsp. of cinnamon and make sure the nuts are a mix of fine and coarse chopped. I only put about 1 to 1.5 tbsp of nut mixture in the layers, as my family doesn't care for it too nut heavy. Make sure your rack is in the middle of the oven and start checking it at 30 minutes to make sure its not going beyond a deep golden color.

text:
I was able to 'build' it by myself without any problems at all. Wet towel, melted butter, no problemo. Assemble everything at hand and turn on the kitchen TV. My syrup turned out perfect. Just a hint: If you don't simmer just under a rolling boil it won't thicken and you'll end up with a watery syrup. If it's not sticky and the consistancy of pancake syrup, cook longer. Even after 4 days the remainder still crunchy from top to bottom. Our guests said it was the best ever. I added grated lemon peal and 1 t. lemon juice. Just fabulous! I will make this every Christmas!

I made this for my fathers birthday.  He loved it!  This recipie is simple and incredibly tasty.  The filo dough is time consuming but the result is worth it.  To respond to the previous review...you don't really know good baklava if you think the bottom shouldn't be a little gooey and sticky.  The yummy sweet honey sauce makes it that way.  Without it baklava would be dry and just taste like chopped nuts.  I will definately make this again.

Wow!  I loved this!  I've never made baklava before but always wanted to try.  I made it for my daughter's Greek Festival at her school and it turned out great!!  I added a couple of dashes of ground cloves to the syrup because I saw a show that said it was traditional to include it. Also, the box of phyllo is enough to make two batches since you cut it in half.  I'll make two next time.  Thanks for the great recipe!!

text:
Wow... so easy! I have never used phyllo dough before so I paid very close attention to the directions on how to handle it. I like the advice about laying it over the edge and folding and only cutting to *near* the bottom. Next time I will do that. The one thing I saw in other recipes was the addition of lemon juice or zest. I can understand how that helps to mellow and cut the sharpness of all the sugar so I did add it. In fact, I used 7/8C of water and 1/8 C of lemon juice with the sugar when I boiled down the syrup. FANTASTIC idea. It's beautiful and delicious. 10 thumbs up!

userID:
2228015
Display Name:
Heather P.
isPro:

followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE this recipe.  I have brought it to a lot of office and holiday parties, and everyone raves.  One Greek person said it was better than his mother's (shhh).  I do only use 1/2 lb walnuts and one roll of the phyllo dough (so, 8oz).  It makes for thinner baklava, but it's very crispy and manages to soak up all of the syrup.  I'm surprised that people have written about cooling the syrup.  I boil it for the last 20 minutes the baklava is baking (YES definitely pre-cut - use a *very* sharp knife so the phyllo doesn't rip or slide), and then you pull the baklava out of the oven and pour the boiling syrup over it immediately...it will run down all the cracks between the diamonds.  As it cools, the syrup becomes thicker and is soaked up by the crispy phyllo.  Yummmmm.  (I am making it again right now...waiting for the first 30 mins to be up so that I can boil the syrup!)  Oh, my pastry brush was kind of rough.  I actually use a Bare Minerals blush brush (new and shampoo'd before using).  The soft bristles barely disturb the phyllo.

text:
After reading everyone's reviews I made 1.5x the amount of sauce, cooled the sauce before pouring it into the hot baklava. This made the baklava intensely sweet, but still very good. Next time I think I'll go with the prescribed amount of sauce so it's not so rich. This recipe calls for an obscene amount of butter. You only need to spread enough butter on the layers to so that they are barely covered. I melted the full cup of butter, and when I was finished I probably didn't use half of it. Next time I'll melt half a stick of butter, then melt more butter as necessary. I used almonds and pecans and it was wonderful. I'll definitely be making this again!

text:
!! LOVE THIS RECIPE-- Just made it last night- for a fundraiser at my local hospital. Everyone who bid today on the baklava plates loved it!!  I will agree with other reviews (THANK YOU FOR THE HELP!!)---yes, make 1/2 more of the syrup- make the syrup first- and refrigerate- definitely toast the nuts (I used Pecans and Walnuts)--put the nuts in a big ziploc bag and beat them well!--USE PARCHMENT PAPER in the baking dish!! and SPARE THE BUTTER-- I ended up making 2  dishes --baked in 9 by 13 inch pyrex glass, and the first round I used WAY to much butter-- GO LIGHT on the butter!! What a great recipe-- this will be in my permanent collection!

userID:
5789466
Display Name:
friedkara
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took into account a lot of suggestions and after reading so many, I have a few of my own.  1) Making 50% more syrup was too much but I managed to salvage the pastry by removing each slice from the pan and putting it into cupcake wrappers immediately (I saved the leftover nut/syrup mix at the bottom of the pan for other uses), 2) it was better the next day because the walnuts had soaked in the syrup, 3) freezing it first before cutting (with a pizza cutter) was a great idea but make sure you cut all the way through. I didn't add sugar to the cinnamon and nuts as there is already a ton of sugar and letting it sit overnight does the trick. I baked at 325 for 50 min rather than 350.  The recipe is inadequate because it doesn't provide nearly enough detail but it has the ingredients right.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Unfortunately these were a big let down. I recently returned from Antalya Turkey, I had Baklava everyday for 2 weeks and they were the best I had ever eaten, I had Baklava in Rhodes Greece 15 years ago which was the first time I tried it, as I had nothing to compare it to I thought they were great, but having made this recipe with phylo bought from the grocery store, I can tell you it is way off what the Turks  use, Turkish Baklava is made with dough alot thinner than phylo evey other country seem to use. "looking through the Turkish dough is like looking through a net curtain" someone said. and it is true, the Baklava there has so many layers of ultra thin phylo, it is almost like puff pastry, with regular phylo you literally feel every layer of pastry as you bite as it is so thick. I know this recipe does not claim to be Turkish, it claims to be Greek, so for that I will give it 2 stars, If you ever get the chance to try Turkish Baklava, I assure you, you will notice the difference, and it is alot better.

text:
I made sure to have every thing ready before inrolling to fillo, nuts , syrup and butter.
Then I did not have to cover the fillo dough just work as fast as possible.
Put about 6 sheets in bottom and 2 every time. Had some nuts left at the end eventhoug I used 3 hipping tablespoons between layers. Should use some more between layers next time.
I did not like, the vanilla flavor of the syrup, it did not taste right  a  baklava. Next time I will use lemon zest or Orange blossom water.
But the overall result was very good.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have used this recipe a few times and I always get rave reviews. I prepare the sauce and the nuts ahead of time. I double the nuts and cinnamon. Also, like others have suggested I use 1 1/2 of the suggested serving for the sauce. I've discovered that a cup of butter is way too much. I would probably only use half of that. If you use too much butter it gets soggy. If you have everything ready ahead of time I have found you don't need to put anything on the phyllo dough to keep it from drying out because the process goes pretty quickly. I usually use the phyllo dough that comes in two rolls. I leave the second roll in the package until I'm ready for it. Love this recipe!!

text:
The end result is worthy of 5 stars, but since I took other reviewers advice, the recipe as written gets four.  Fabulous base recipe.  I did add a little squeeze of lemon and it's zest and increased syrup by a half, making it in advance so it could cool before pouring it over the hot baklava.  It makes a key difference.  I've made this several times, and everyone who eats it proclaims that it's the best baklava they've ever eaten, anywhere!  Yes,it does take time and care to make, but I consider it a labour of love, especially when I gift whole pans of it to people I care about when they need cheering up!

country:
None
text:
I have a friend that loves baklava and I decided to take on the challenge for him. After reading the reviews, I made 1.5x the sauce and put it in the fridge to cool while I made the baklava. Some here said they added sugar to the nut and cinnamon mix but I didn't want it to be too sweet so I added just a small amount of brown sugar to it. I got it in the oven at 325 since some reviews said 350 was too high. Once it was golden on top I took it out and poured the cold sauce onto it immediatly. I had made sure to not make my cuts all the way through so the bottom wouldn't get soggy. I let it sit for a bit and then tried a bite. Heaven.  I took some in for my friend and he said it was perfect and that I must be part Greek ;) He isn't one to sugarcoat the truth either, so I trusted him.

text:
AMAZING! I followed the directions as stated, except making sure to cut only 3/4 through the baklava before baking. I have made this using all walnuts and a mix of walnuts and pistachios. Although shelling the pistachios is a pain, they make the baklava taste much more authentic and delicious! For the butter, I melt it in a bowl and apply with a pastry brush. I usually make a half recipe in an 8X8 pan, baked for 40 minutes. This is one of my very favorite dessert recipes! Thank you!

userID:
4931566
Display Name:
cookintraining
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
439
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My first attempt took forever.  First of all, I burned the nuts when I toasted them ($10 worth), so I had to dash to the store.  Secondly, I was once told (unfortunately) that the size of a pan was determined by measuring the bottom.  So, my first mistake (besides the burnt nuts) was using a pan that was too large.  Consequently, a sheet of phyllo cut in half wasn't large enough to fill the pan.  So, I instead cut it to fit and used the smaller scraps patched together.  This meant that I ran out of phyllo sheets long before I had used all the nut filling.  The dough was dry to begin with, and I didn't have enough of the filling, but the end result, although not pretty, was delicious and loved by all.  Next time, smaller pan, and I'll watch the toasting of the nuts carefully.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-05-01T19:10:02.56

Wow! This recipe is really good!! I make this all the time now and it's the only baklava recipe I use. I make this mainly during Christmas time, so I use chopped pecans and walnuts as the chopped nuts. I don't like pistachios, but I'm sure that they would be really good in this recipe too!

Display Name:
linelle707

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for the first time yesterday to share with friends at a slide show of my recent trip to the Holy Land. It was a huge and dazzling success. People asked me where I had bought them.

I searched long and hard for a recipe that sounded right also successful adaptations. I followed this recipe, but made 1.5 times the syrup. I used a mixture of pecans and pistachios (hate walnuts). Since I used a 1-lb. pkg of phyllo in two plastic wrapped portions, I used one at a time and didn't need the damp cloth over them, just a covering of wax paper which didn't stick. The only difficulty I had was when cutting them before baking, the top layer wanted to lift off, so I had to use care. After baking, I realized the pieces were way too big, so I cut each in half and it was very easy to do, so I'm thinking I can do some/all of the cutting after baking next time. I cooled the syrup and poured on the baklava straight from the oven. No sogginess, just decadent crispy wonderfulness. It cost about $15 and is time intensive, but really not difficult. I was a heroine!!

text:
Tried this for the first time today. Took a couple other posters advice about adding sugar to the nuts and 1.5 X the syrup. It has a great flavor but is a little soggy. Of course, it may have been less soggy if my hubby and I hadn't been so anxious to try it. I will definitely make this again. I think experience will help me get the amount of syrup right. I also cooled the syrup in the fridge while I assembled and baked it. 

I have never used Phyllo before and was pleasantly surprised at how easy it was to handle. I am also lucky to have ample counter space next to my stove and just placed a saucepan on low on a burner and placed the baking pan right next to it. Only took about 10 minutes to layer the pastry and nuts. 40 minutes was adequate time to bake it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Believe the hype.  This was my first attempt at baklava and it might be the best I've ever had.  It's also conducive to making adjustments as you go along.  I did find that I needed 1 1/2 times the sauce, and also more nut mixture, since I used 3 Tbsp (ok more like 3 "heaping" Tbsp LOL) per layer.  Both were no big deal to throw together, just keep your dough covered with plastic & a damp towel so it stays pliable.  I think if you use 3 Tbsp per layer you will need about 25% more nut mixture than the recipe calls for.  The cinnamon tastes beautiful, the layers are crispy and the filling is juicy.  Love it, love it, love it!!!  Thank you so much for this recipe!!!!

text:
A little disappointed beause I had high expectations for this recipe. For the amount of work put into this, it turned out to be just okay and it didn't taste authentic. Also, for someone like me who always felt intimidated by the thought of making baklava, the instructions were a bit off and it made me a little frustrated. Every little detail really mattered to me but I still managed even though it took me awhile to finish.  I did not cut the dough to make it fit, instead, I just laid it then fold it over so that you have 2 layers. Someone also mentioned to butter every other dough but I had lightly buttered every single one. If I decide to make this again, I will probably do a pistachio/walnut mix and try to find a better syrup.

text:
I found the recipe instructions confusing. I didn't have to cut my phyllo in half. I used whole pieces which fit the pan perfectly. Also, the butter needs to be fully melted to liquid. A butter brush is needed. I didn't realize that you only butter every other pastry sheet and I buttered every one by mistake. There are 40 sheets per standard box of phyllo dough.  You should retain the waxy paper that comes in the package to layer between the damp towel and the phyllo stack. My baklava came out too soggy (too much butter?) and the tops curled up. But overall not too bad.

userID:
753310
Display Name:
kelcampbell
isPro:
False
followersCount:
154
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
712
favoritesCount:
1945
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3294500.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So good!  I made a rookie mistake when grinding the nuts though - I put whole almonds, pistachios and pecans into the food processor along with walnut "crumbs" (small pieces) and started to pulse away - well because the walnuts were so much smaller than everything else, if I had kept going, I would have ended up with walnut powder.  So in the end, my nuts were not as finely chopped as I would have liked. For the layering, I did 10 sheets of phyllo then 1/3 of the nuts, 6 sheets, another 1/3rd nuts, 6 sheets, last 1/3rd and then topped with 9 sheets of phyllo.  The nut mixture was good, but I felt there was too much cinnamon, so I will reduce next time (I also added 1/4 cup sugar and 1/2 tsp allspice to nuts). For the sauce, I made 1 1/2 times the amount and added about a 2" strip of orange rind.  I think it might be too much sauce, but the jury is still out on that. The only other thing I will change next time is to press down on everything before baking as my top layer of phyllo didn't seem to stick to the last layer of nuts.  Once the baklava was out of the oven, I poured the cooled sauce over everything and topped each piece with a pinch of finely ground pistachios for that 'authentic' look.  The end result was fantastic - we can't stop eating them!

text:
This was very good and waaay simpler than I ever expected. Only had to use half of a phyllo dough box and it was plenty of sheets. Next time, I would make the amount of syrup called for, I increased it by a half this time and it was too much. Chill the syrup and put it on in waves so it doesn't all seep to the bottom. I would use more nuts next time. I also added some cardamom and lemon zest. Boil cloves and cardamom with the sugar syrup. Only need 1 stick of butter.

text:
I was nervous to work with the phyllo dough, but it was easier than I expected. I used walnuts and actually substituted the butter with Earth Balance buttery spread to keep it non-dairy and cut back on fat. My BF couldn't keep his hands off! I would suggest doing a larger layer of phyllo on the bottom to make it more stable. I would also suggest doing less layers with more sheets in between. Definitely chill the sauce and don't cut all the way to the bottom before baking. Also, I found a serrated knife helped for a clean cut.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made as written and although it seemed too dry at first, after storing in the freezer it comes out as perfect as any I've ever had. I think it just needs time to "meld". Also, the top layers need a little buttering, too, to keep them from curling. I cut it into squares before baking, then cut those in half after baking to form the triangles that fit better into the muffin papers. I stacked those in a plastic container which I put in the freezer - it never actually "freezes" because of the butter/sugar content. I take out a little as I need it and it's ready to serve in no time! (yes, I take out a piece once in a while and microwave for 10 seconds - heaven!)Thank you to those who pointed out that you should cut almost to the bottom but not all the way!

userID:
1580761
Display Name:
phoenix__rising
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
23
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe got rave reviews at 2 holiday parties and from family and friends. It is the best! I only used one roll out of the 16 oz. phyllo box. I did not cut the dough in half. I unrolled the dough, put it on a cookie sheet, covered it with a piece of saran wrap and a wet hand towel. I recovered the dough each time I took out a sheet. I used whole sheets of phyllo and put them into my 13x9 glass baking dish. The sheets were a little large, but I just buttered and pushed them down a bit and it worked fine. At first, the butter was hard to spread and the phyllo tore. I put the butter in a small mixing bowl in the microwave and made it creamy (but not liquid), then used a pastry brush to really slop it onto the phyllo. Bottom layer was 2 sheets, in between were 1 sheet layers each buttered individually, and the top was 8 sheets. Each layer also got 3-4 T of chopped walnut mixture. The SECRET to this recipe is buttering and topping every single sheet and using a quality honey. (I bought my honey from a local bee keeper. at the farm market.)  Other than procedure, I didn't change a thing in this recipe. The sauce and everything is perfect as is. This recipe will be a Christmas Eve tradition from now on. Enjoy it with authentic Espresso or cappucino, and it's even more phenomenal. Thanks for a wonderful recipe. This is a keeper-- and now that I'm done with my review, I have to give 9 other people the recipe who asked me for it!

text:
I made this a few weeks ago for some Romanian friends who came to visit. I used sandra lee's suggestions of "draping the bottom half over the pan and then folding the top half over it, "painting" a thin layer of butter quickly," (it made it so easy!) and "cut to within a half inch FROM the bottom of the pan." After it cooled, it was a little tough to cut through with my only sharp utility knife, and I wasn't sure if I had spread enough butter on each layer, as the top didn't seem to stick as well as I had expected, but the final verdict was an "A+". Thanks so much NEONWILLIE for such a great recipe!

city:

country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe!.  To make it even easier though, my grandmoter taught me to use two pieces of philo dough on the bottom, butter the top of the two, then two more buttered on the top one and then put a nice amount of nuts on one end of the philo dough and roll it up from that end.  It's quick, it's easy and you don't have to butter each individual sheet.  She brushes the top of the roll with butter once its rolled and then places in a lined cookie sheet with the rolls all next to eachother, cut and bake same amount of time.  Because it's rolled it doesn't fall apart as easily, easier to hold.
Review:

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been cooking for over five decades and hubby and I are former restaurant owners (I made the pastries, etc.), and used this recipe for the first time a few days ago. The next day, we brought it to a party filled with foodies and world travellers. It was the absolute hit of the party, and I have never heard as many compliments on a dish as I did that night. I followed the directions and some tips from readers, made the sauce ahead of time and chilled it (doubled sauce recipe and used leftover to pour at table), and used walnuts which I chopped medium-fine in my Cuisinart. The only tricky part is buttering the layers - must be done with a light touch to prevent them from shifting and/or tearing. It really helped to have hubby remove the defrosted phyllo sheets from the package as we worked, lay them in the pan, and I followed up with spreading the butter and sprinkling the nuts. Team work! Living here in Florida, I used orange-blossom honey, which added a pleasant touch. We have a convection oven, but I still used 350 degrees and checked after 20, 30, and about 40 minutes.  This recipe went in front of my "Desserts" file, to be made many times in the future. Thanks, original poster and tipsters!

text:
This is a great dessert! I use a recipe for baklava from Egyptian cuisine. I use walnuts, sugar, butter and cinnamon for the filling. You may no use honey in the syrup. Greek-style baklava uses honey, but more typical Arabic baklava doesn`t. Pour hot syrup over cool baklava or cool syrup over hot baklava.

Even I couldn't believe I had made this it was so good! My husband stops at a middle eastern resturant and buys dessert for the family once in a while. He said this was better. I did as others suggested and cooked the syrup first and let it completely cool and then poured it over the baklava while it was still hot. I also added 1/4 cup of sugar to the nut mixture. Thanks for a great recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
the recipe itself is good, although the actual baking instructions are incredibly unclear. So for  those people who didn't understand, you are supposed to stack 4 layers of 2 sheets of dough, with a coating of butter in between. There will be 3 sections. Each section is comprised of 4 layers. The 2nd section, the one in the middle, will be made up of the same 4 layers, but add the nut mixture along with the butter that separates the layers. Then add your 3rd section, of 4 layers. I wish I had realized this before I messed up the first batch. But the actual recipe is great.

text:
This was great!! I followed some of the other reviewers tips. It wasn't as hard as I thought it would be. My mother in law bought some at a middle eastern bakery & told me mine was better! The advice about the 1 1/2 times the sauce is perfect. I did add a little more cinnamon, my husband's personal preference. Also I followed the advice about using a spray bottle for the butter. That was so easy! I placed all of the dough over the edge of the pan & covered it as I was using it. That was a really handy tip. For my first time it only took my about 20 minutes to put together. Follow the tip about putting hot sauce on cooled baklava ( or vice versa). And only cutting the baklava to within 1/2 inch from bottom when you bake it mine wasn't soggy at all. I will defiantly be making this again!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this following the recipe and some of the suggested tweaks by reviewers.  I did 1 1/2x the sauce, and made the sauce ahead so it was chilled before pouring on the baked baklava, which was a good suggestion.  2 things to mention:  of the 16 oz. of finely chopped nuts (pecans) I prepared, by following the recipe and adding 3 T. to each layer, I ended up with 6 oz. of nuts leftover.  So if you want it really nutty, do 4-5 T. or just buy about 10 oz. (what I will do when I make this again).  Also, I followed someone's suggestion and poured my melted butter into a sprayer (emptied out I-Can't-Believe-It's-Not-Butter) to "spritz" the phyllo dough with.  I thought I spritzed pretty generously, and the baklava came out well, but again I had a lot of leftover melted butter... probably 1/2 of what I started with.  So if you spritz, you can use less butter with a good result.  All in all, a very yummy recipe.  Have fun!

text:
This recipe is so easy for a first timer, and the phyllo dough was not as hard to work with as I thought it was going to be. I did take some of the other reviewer's suggestions like keeping the dough covered with plastic wrap while working and making the sauce ahead of time. Next time I will try the tip of someone who suggested using a butter spray bottle instead of a brush to butter the dough. I tried to use butter sparingly in each layer, but it still came out a little moist at the bottom. I would suggest making it the day before needed and leaving it uncovered on the counter overnight. Keeps it crisp and flavorful. This was a real hit with my company.

Display Name:
Jan

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is by far the best tasting baklava I have ever had!  It was not overly sweet and nearly tasted like apple pie from the cinnamon.  The top layers were crisp as well as the bottom layer.
Very easy recipe to follow for the novice baker, and the advice given by other reviewers was very helpful. 
I made the sauce and the nut mixture 1 day in advance; fortunately, the phyllo dough I had purchased was already cut into sheets, so assembly was quick.  Instead of brushing the melted butter onto the sheets, I dabbed it.  But, I would cut the baklava into shapes BEFORE adding the melted butter to the very top layer, otherwise it will rip easily during the cutting.  I also made 1-1/2 of the sauce recipe and it was just right!  That idea came from another reviewer.  Only pre-cut the shapes 3/4 of the way (another reviewer tip).  So, my only advice is to read the recipe and reviewer comments carefully, taking notes, before you begin.

text:
This is an awesome recipe, and very easy to assemble. My phyllo sheets came 18 to a box, so I allocated the bottom, top, and middle layers accordingly (i.e.count sheets and plan ahead for the correct amount of filling--I used pecans--for each layer). My husband, who is a baklava nut, thought this was the best he'd ever had, even considering the professionally made ones!

None
text:
After reading several reviews...I followed these helpful suggestions to make this baklava the closest to the consistency that I like.  1.  I ground the nuts as fine as I could--very, very fine.  2.  Made the syrup up earlier and let cool completely & then poured the cooled syrup onto hot baklava.  3.  Did not over use the butter, tried to very lightly cover each sheet.  I did use clarified butter a.k.a. Ghee--it allows for cooking with butter at a higher heat.  This recipe will be a Christmas cookie staple from now on!

Truly enjoyed this as did my coworkers.  Purchased bagged nuts already chopped.  Used walnuts and pecans.  Added 1t. almond extract to the sauce in addition to 1 1/2 t. of finely scraped orange rind.  Like other reviewers suggested made sauce first(50% more as suggested) and then cooled sauce before it was poured onto the baklava.  Also used 3 sticks of butter instead of two and doubled the cinnamon. Most of those who ate it told me that it was the best they've had.  Yum delicious!!!!

text:
This recipe is great.I used raw almonds and dried cranberries. I did follow the suggestion of making the sauce ahead of time and letting it cool and then ladled it over the baklava when it came out of the oven. I did let the phyllo defrost in the fridge over night and let it get to room temp prior to assembly. Use the moist towel over the plastic wrap, it will keep it from sticking to the phyllo. I used a pastry brush to apply the butter to the layers and I needed to use 1.5 cups of butter. A keeper!

text:
I looooove this baklava!  I have a taste for it a lot and this is absolutely the best tasting baklava I've ever eaten.  It's pretty simple to make. I was a little worried my first time, because I've never worked with phyllo dough before, but it turned out fantastic!  I made 1 1/2 times the sauce and used about 1 1/3 stick of butter.  I always make the sauce first and let it cool for a long time.  *For a delicious and exotic twist, I add a pinch of safron to the sauce when I'm simmering it.*  It comes out sooooo good.  This is definately a keeper and it tastes as good as the restaurants/bakeries.

text:
This recipe made great baklava. I followed the recipe as written with one exception—I buttered each sheet of phyllo, not every two. As a result, I used about 1/2 cup more butter. I thought the key to making it wasy was preparation. I started the syrup to cook, then chopped the nuts, followed by melting the butter. Then I dampened the towel and opened the phyllo and started assembly. Excellent results!

text:
We have a Greek festival in our town every year and get unbeatable baklava there.  This recipe is very comparable. I added a bit of honey to the melted butter and brushed it on every layer. I would suggest max 2 layers phyllo between fillings, I did 1 layer. Hubby likes it better that way because his Armenian grandfather made it that way. Also, I sprinkled a tad of ground cloves on top before baking. Baklava is surprisingly easy.

text:
My first attempt at making Baklava and it turned out great! I slightly melted the butter and used a pastry brush to apply it. Also, because the phyllo is so delicate, and because I'm a huge fan of parchment paper, I used a sheet of it to assemble and cut the baklava on before transferring it to a baking pan. Then of course, when the baklava was finished and cooled, I simply lifted the paper out of the pan and was ready to go! Delicious!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made many diffrent baklava recipes, and this one is the best I've found.  There are still a few changes I've made:  I use a cinnamon/sugar mixture to toss with the nuts, it makes it more evenly distributed instead of just using cinnamon, which sometimes clumps up.  Also, for the syrup, I omit the vanilla and add 1/2 tsp shredded lemon peel, 2 tbsp. lemon juice, and just a sprinkling of cinnamon.  Authentic, traditional baklava has just a hint of lemon in it.

JENSPIN

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow - this is a great recipe!  It turned out beautifully - not tooth-numbingly sweet or drippy and soggy like other baklava I've had.  I took the advice of reviewers and made the syrup well in advance and allowed it to cool before pouring it over the hot baklava.  I also simmered an extra 10 minutes to get it to the consistency of syrup.  I rolled up the leftover phyllo sheets and sliced the roll into thin shreds and scattered them on top before baking.  I highly recommend this recipe, particularly if you think you don't like baklava!

text:
This is by far a 5++++++ recipe--I am impressed! I didn't think this would turn out as good as it did because it looked so simple.  After reading the reviews for this recipe I decided I had to try it....it turned out beautiful and delicious! The only variation I made was that I added about 1 cup of miniature chocolate chips to the nut mixture (I used 8oz of pecans, and 8oz of walnuts). I buttered and crumbled leftover "scraps" of the fillo roll and placed them loosly on top of the Baklava for a decorative touch. I also only baked for only 45-min. Any longer and this would have burned for me. Thank you so much, Donna for sharing this wonderful recipe!

None
text:
MUCH easier than previous baklava recipes I've used, and every bit as good as what my Greek relatives make!  A tip to make it easier still -- before you cut the baklava, put the pan in the fridge or freezer, as it makes the phyllo easier (or at least neater) to cut.  I used lemon extract instead of lemon zest in the syrup, and it worked well.  I also agreed with the reviewer who said you'd need to use more than a few tablespoons of nuts in each layer; I think I probably used about 1/4 cup of nuts (the traditional Greek way is to use walnuts) in each layer.  Great stuff!

text:
For those having difficulty with the phyllo/fillo: Put the dough down on the counter, then put a sheet of plastic wrap on top of that, and THEN the damp cloth. Keeps the dough from drying out, and also keeps the top layer from getting gummy. This recipe was so easy to make - I'm making more tonight! I, too, doubled the sauce and let it cool before pouring it over the hot baklava. Also, I poured it about 1/3 at a time, let it soak in, poured some more, let it soak in, etc. Seemed to work well. Mmmm!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We make this every year at Passover.  Here are some tips we use to make them light and crispy:
*Not too much butter on each sheet, just paint a thin layer of butter
*when cutting don't cut thru all layers, just cut thru up to 1/4 inch from bottom layer, that way the sauce stays in the baklava and doesn't end up in the bottom of the pan
*we make one and half of the sauce recipe
*make sauce ahead and place in fridge to cool.  When you pour cool sauce on warm baklava it turns out crispy
*reduce 1 cup of water to 1/2
*increase 1/2 cup honey to 1 cup
*add 1/2 cup of sugar into nut mixture

text:
Never made baklava before so I tried this a couple of days ago and was a big hit. I did 1.5 batch of the syrup as suggested. I found I needed 2 packets of antoniou fillo pastry (I had lots of wastage from cutting around the edge to fit my pan). I bought raw mixed nuts and roasted them for about 10 minutes , tossing them half way through. It did take me about an hour to construct but the layering was easy to do and somewhat therapeutic :)
I rate the success of this recipe on my Greek born father who absolutely loved it so to me it's a keeper :)

FABULOUSLY EASY...just a couple things, i melted the butter and put it in a spray bottle which was much quicker and easier plus i used half the butter. second i add a tsp of cocoa to my nut mixture i find it adds a bit more body to the taste i love it..make your syrop first and put it in the fridge to get cold before you port it on the hot baklava that way it doesn't get soggy..

I always thought Baklava would be so difficult to make but I was pleasanly suprised at how simple this was. I made it for my co-workers and it was gone byt the end of the day. They all loved it!! I did half pistachios and half pecans and added a pinch of cardamom to the nut mixture. I also added a few drops of lemon juice and about a teaspoon of rose water to the honey mixture. It made the taste wonderful!! The first batch I did got a little too done so I reduced the time for the second and they came out prefect!!

Display Name:
WasntMeSB

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/441687.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the first time I've made Baklava, and it was easy and wonderful!  Don't be afraid of using the phyllo dough.  As long as you keep a damp towel over it and use MELTED butter to brush it with, it is easy to work with. To keep the syrup from pooling on the bottom, some have recommended not cutting all the way through, but you will find it difficult to cut once it is baked and very flaky.  The key to adding the syrup is to allow it to cool and thicken, and be sure to pour it on the Baklava as soon as it comes out of the oven.  The hot pan makes the syrup cook into the Baklava and keeps it from pooling in the bottom of the pan.   I used Walnuts and added an extra 1/2 tsp of cinnamon to the nuts. Try this recipe! You'll love it.

I love this recipe, it's so easy to make!! I use a mix of pistachio and walnuts, but I'm sure it would taste good with whatever nuts you have lying around.  I took the advice of other reviewers and moved the baklava out of the pan as soon as possible. I am going to keep an eye on them in the oven the next time I make these because I took them out at 40 minutes and they were a little too brown.

Display Name:
KBark

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6203544.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the first time I have ever eaten baklava let alone make it. I started with this recipe but ended up combining it with the recipe on the back of the phyllo dough package. I used 1 1/2 portions of sauce as recommended by other reviewers. Mixed 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1/8 tsp cloves, 1/2 cup sugar with 5 cups of toasted mixed nuts (2 1/2 cups walnuts, 1 1/2 cups pecans, 1 cup pistachios). Butter each sheet of dough (8 @ a time), layer 8 sheets, 1 2/3 cups nuts, repeat twice. 16 sheets on top, bake @ 325 for 55 minutes. Pour refrigerated sauce on hot baklava...delicious!!

text:
Absolutely wonderful! My first attempt making baklava and it was a hit over the Christmas holiday.  A rookie note, make sure you defrost the phyllo in the fridge overnight. Attempts to defrost don't turn out like you would think, but you can still use broken phyllo and no one will know, so long as it's not the top layer!

text:
This was fabulous.  I haven't had baklava in years.  I followed sandra lee's suggestions.  It only took me about 12 minutes to assemble.  I already had the butter melted and ground the nuts and added cinnamon.  I shouldn't have baked for 50 minutes.  I think I should have checked about 40 minutes.  It was a lot more golden than I've ever had before.  Still very good.  I was surprised that when I poured the cooled sauce over the baked baklava, it snap crackled and popped.  I made it 5 days ago.  We didn't cover it because of the hint.  It's still good--not soggy at all.  It will be finished tonight.

text:
I tried this for the first time for my 84 yr old mother for Christmas.I was nervous,having never worked with phyllo dough.I decided to go with Sara Bear's tips,only making 1 1/2 times the sauce.(3/4 cup water,1 1/2 cup honey.) and with a little sugar in with the nuts.She didn't say if she cut the sugar ,since there was so much more honey.So, I think I only put about 1/4 cup sugar in the syrup.I didn't know if that would make the sauce too thin.But I refrigerated the sauce for a couple hours til I got around to doing the rest.Well, my mother said it was as good if not better than any she had eaten..I was so glad.Oh, and I baked it at 325 for 50 minutes.But it depends on your oven.I have gas....and I know electric can burn faster.

text:
This came out BEAUTIFULLY. My only hints are to make the sauce before the rest of the pastry so it can cool completely by the time you pull the rest out of the oven, and to only cut the pastry about 2/3 of the way through so the sauce soaks into all levels and doesn't just sit on the bottom and make it soggy.

I was told to cut this part way through before baking it, and I think that actually helped. It came out very hard and I don't think I could have cut it after baking. But, then again, it could have been hard because I cut it early. Even though it was hard, it tasted incredible and I couldn't stop eating it. I think if I ever make baklava again, I would either not cut it early or use another recipe, but I may never make it again because it took me forever to layer everything. I gave this recipe 3 stars because it was delicious but hard and took a long time to make.

text:
This is an amazing recipe. The concept is very easy - but working with the phyllo dough takes some patience! Once you get past that, it's actually not a very complicated and uses mostly ingredients that you already have in the house, so you will likely only have to pick up the dough and nuts. I had my oven at 325 for 40 minutes (not 350 for 50 minutes) and it still started to burn - so I will definitely go with a lower heat next time. This baklava is delicious and impressive!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After the first time I made this, I was asked to make it for a wedding, it's that good! I made it for the wedding and had some leftover and took it to my son's ballgame and got raves from everyone there who had some. Fabulous recipe! Easy to make. Some of the tips I picked up before making it were to butter the layers VERY lightly. I think I only used about a 1/2 cup of melted butter instead of a cup. I also don't cover the dough while layering. I find it's actually easier to use when it starts to dry out. Don't worry about the dough tearing or wrinkling, you can't tell once it's cooked. Also, let the sauce cool before pouring over. Definitely a great recipe!

text:
Wow! This is fabulous. I did make a few mistakes though please read on to prevent the same errors. 1.Chop the nuts up finely, mine were more coursely chopped and I ended up having sheets of dough left over and it would have been better if there had been more layers. 2. Also, I followed the advice of other reviewers and made more sauce - I ended up with sauce left over. So next time I will just follow the recipe and not make extra. 3. I liked someone else's suggestion to cut it with a pizza cutter, that worked very well except on the edges where I used a knife. 4. I did not use a whole cup of butter. I would melt just half a cup and than melt more later if your run out that way you won't end up with a bunch of leftover melted butter.

text:
This was my first attempt at Baklava and having experienced somebody else's version which I remember as being exceptionally good, I wasn't totally satisfied with it- although everybody who tried it, loved it. I made the mistake of using cheap crushed peanuts when I should have splashed out and used fresh walnuts and almonds. Either it was the nuts or the cooking time, but the edges were slightly overcooked and the top was a bit too flaky and crispy, so I'll decrease the cooking time slightly. I've searched for other Baklava recipes and have come across one which includes citrus peel, lemon juice, cinnammon sticks, nutmeg, cloves, and double the honey. I'll include these ingredients next time. I'll also try somebody's suggestion of using rose water in place of normal water for the syrup.

x46807

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Caution!  This is a decent recipe, but it will turn out wrong if you follow it word for word.  Two things to change:  1.  Do not cut the baklava before you bake it.  2.  Do not pour the sauce on until after the baklava has cooled for a few minutes.  The point of the sauce is to soak into the dough, to some extent.  However, if you cut the dough first, the sauce just drips through the cuts and collects in the bottom.  Also, pouring the sauce into the hot 9x13 pan just causes it to turn into a sticky gummy goo around the edges.

I recommend waiting until the pan cools a little before pouring the sauce on, letting it cool, refrigerating overnight, and then cutting it after the sauce has soaked in.  That is just from my experience making baklava before - I thought this recipe was a little odd.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-11-04T05:29:18.113

text:
Definitely use a spritzer bottle for the melted butter, it cuts down on the time.  It made the assembly easy and effortless!  Also, up the sugar mixture to half more than what the recipe says.  Lastly, use a *serrated* knife to cut through the pastry.  Clean cuts are the key to making the ultimate outcome pretty.  Save about 4 tablespoons for after you drizzle the sugar mixture and then sprinkle them on top.  Also, toast all the nut prior, for extra deliciousness.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2008-07-19T10:57:58.88

userID:
2512485
Display Name:
Carmen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
56
favoritesCount:
4
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this several times, and it's an amazing recipe as written. I can't believe how easy it is to make a dessert that looks so intimidating. I tried making Alton Brown's baklava recipe as well, but this one is definitely better. Over time, I've made my own additions to the recipe, including what I thought were successes from other recipes. I used a combination of walnuts, almonds, and pistachios. I add 1/2- to 3/4 of a tsp allspice to the nuts, a tsp of rose water to the water, and throw a 1-inch piece of citrus peel into the syrup. I use Athens brand phyllo dough, because it fits perfectly into a 9x13 inch pan. As one reviewer suggested, when you cut the baklava before you bake it, use a sharp knife and cut into it within a half inch from the bottom of the pan, so then when you pour the sauce into the cooled baklava, the sauce seeps into every layer of the Baklava, but doesn't sit at the bottom. Then, cut all the way thru after the whole thing has completely cooled. This is an elegant dessert, portions out perfectly for parties, makes you look like a baking pro, and very easy to prepare (although somewhat time-consuming, if you're new to making it, but it's well worth the effort).
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-07-16T16:10:30.3
helpfulCount:

userID:

text:
My family was blown away by this baklava recipe.  I used much more butter than the recipe called for, simply because I wanted to make sure all the dough was covered, but I think it worked out well because the baklava turned out very, very moist.  For the nuts, I used a bag of pecans which I chopped into very tiny pieces.  The result was great.  Even my husband, who often buys fresh, handmade baklava at the local farmers' market, said this was the best baklava he's had! Next time I may try adding a bit of ground cloves to give it a little kick.

userID:

Display Name:
sarabeara

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So good and easy to follow.  I buy the chopped [baking] walnuts from Trader Joe's.   The 1st time I used them as is, but because the pieces were still quite large, I only had enough for 2 nut layers, and the baklava fell apart easily.  The 2nd time, I ground the walnuts in a blender (though not completely because some texture is desirable) such that I had enough for 4 nut layers that stayed together in the end.  I make 1.5x sauce mixture before I start layering and baking, so that it has substantial time to simmer and cool down.  I like to cut mine in triangles, diamonds, or squares and serve them on black Japanese serving trays - one large round one, and a smaller rectangular one.  It makes for a great presentation, and the baklava fits perfectly on the 2 dishes.

text:
I read some reviews and made the syrup ahead of time so that it would be cooled when poured on the baklava.  In addition, I made some changes of my own...I took 3/4 c. brandy and 2 c. dried cranberries, brought the brandy to a boil, added the cranberries and covered with a lid and let them sit for 15 minutes.  I then drained them and chopped them.  I also added a bar of white baking chocolate that was finely chopped and sprinkled chocolate & cranberries on with the nuts on each layer.  My friend (who requested I make baklava) told me in advance he was a 
"plain latte" kind of person and did not think he would like the cranberry/choc combo.  He knows differently now as he has asked me to make this again next week!

I have never made baklava before and pretty much forgotten what it tasted like, it's been so long since I've had it.  I followed others suggestions to 1 1/2 times the honey mixture. I love baklava, and although I've wanted to make it for a long time, I was always scared off by the phyllo dough--no longer! This recipe was simple and incredibly good. I made a pan of this for my boyfriend instead of a birthday cake, and it vanished! My only difficulty was in getting the top piece of phyllo to stay put while I cut the baklava into diamonds. I will admit that reading this, I was intimidated.  I have never used phyllo dough before.  After the first layer of nuts, I found it a bit challenging to butter the phyllo.  So I melted the butter in a cup and used a pastry brush to brush it on.  I also used "I can't believe it's not butter".  I used pistachios and this turned out so good.  My neighbors are middle eastern descent and his mom told me that this was delicious!  Thank you so much for sharing this with me!

text:
This was awesome!  I didn't find the directions very clear about the last several layers.  I'm assuming you do not need the entire 16 oz. package of dough, and when you run out of nuts you just repeat a few layers of dough only, just like on the bottom.  That's what I did, and it was phenomenal.  Other reviewers recommended making extra sauce, but I found the original recipe to be plenty.  Otherwise it would have been too sweet.  This was so good, and it's definitely going in my recipe collection.

text:
I made this on Sunday. I followed other suggestions. Use toasted pecans- I crushed them in a baggie and toasted them dry in a pan for 5 minutes. I added 1/4 C. sugar with nuts and cinnamon. For sauce I used 1/2 C. water and 1 C. honey. I brought to a boil for about 8 minutes only and spooned on hot Baklava. Also, I used 1/2 C. melted butter and used a pastry brush to spread it over 4 layers of phyllo at a time. It was much less time consuming and so easy. It was gone in minutes at lunch today. Incredible!It was my first time making this!I have several requests already.

I was craving baklava and am soo happy to find this recipe and with the result.It is an effort making this but well worth it.After reading the reviews i took advice and covered the fillo dough with plastic wrap and a damp sheet..worked well...used lots of melted unsalted margarine with a brush and a combination of Pistashios,Walnuts and Almonds. Also added 1/2 cup of castor sugar and a sprinkle of cardamon powder to the nuts. Also added a tablespoon of lemon juice to the sauce. To keep the fillo from curling, sprinkle a bit of water just before baking and make sure to cut all the way to the bottom before and after baking.Pouring cooled sauce over hot baklava really helps from preventing it becoming soggy. Thanku so much for a great recipe..will definitely be making more of this again.Soo Good !!

text:
This recipe, and the results, are absolutely outstanding!  I got rave reviews the first time I made it!  People think that making baklava is difficult; it's not, it just requires patience.  From the other reviews I took the following advice: I made 1.5x the sauce, let it cool completely and poured over the hot pastry.  Also, I sure was glad I cut the pieces before I baked it.  FYI, I used a combination of walnuts and pecans, just because that's what I had on hand...tasted great!  Thanks, Donna, for this awesome recipe!

text:
Well I made this 4 days ago and am about to make it again.  For anyone incompetent like me I found cutting messed up my top layer of filo pastry so this time will stick an extra layer that can be removed after cutting (just for neatness sake).

From previous reviews I presumed I should buy filo pastry from the freezer but they have it in the fridges and I ran my dryer so the room was really humid (didn't use the wet cloth) and the pastry didn't become brittle.  Enjoy!

Display Name:
Ting Young

city:

region:

country:

text:
Good basic recipe.Here are differences that I made from the original recipe and some useful tips:1. I made the sauce first. I used 1 cup each of water, sugar, and honey.  I added some lemon zest in the sauce too. After done cooking it, I put it in the freezer right away with a towel underneath. This allowed the sauce to get really cold after my baklava was baked. 2. I chopped 1lb of walnuts and added half tsp of nutmeg and a quarter cup of brown sugar in the nut mix too. 3. I bought my phyllo sheets at Wegmans. It's a Wegmans brand, and it's $2.99 per pack. It's 16oz per pack with 2 rolls, sized 9X13. It fits perfectly with a 9X13 baking pan. I used 2 rolls.  I thawed them in room temperature for 30 minutes. There was no need to cover it with damped towels, because I assembled my baklava very fast, less than 15 minutes. You may need it unless it takes you so long to do it.4.  Every time I picked up two phyllo sheets together to layer and brush butter lightly on top of them. A good pastry brush does help to apply butter fast and easy.  My pastry brush is KitchenAid, it works well.5. I sprinkled 3 tbsp nuts mix, it worked out just right with all the layers. 6. When I cut the assembled baklava, I did follow other people's tip that not to cut all the way to the bottom. That did help to prevent the sauce soaked down the bottom and make the bottom layers soggy. It made the nuts layers more sticky crunch.7. I used 2 sticks of butter. I melted it in the microwave and put the containe

text:
I recommend making the syrup first and then letting it cool completely while assembling and cooking the baklava. You might even put the syrup in the fridge. It is best to put COLD syrup into the hot baklava, as soon as you take the baklava from the oven. Hot syrup on hot baklava makes a soggy mess.

userID:
22871842
Display Name:
Leanne

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe three times. Each time I changed it up, just slightly. I used extra butter and extra sauce. Someone rated this recipe three stars and indicated the sauce was too thin; however, I found the sauce to be just the right consistency. If the sauce was any thicker it would not seep into the layers as well!  Also, I found if you cut only half through before baking, pour the sauce over after removing from the oven, allow to cool, then cut the rest of the way through. This allows the sauce to seep into layers nicely!  Great recipe!

The recipe on this is not very precise. if you are using a 9/13 inch pan, you need a phyllo dough that's 9/14 inch phyllo dough which is available in the supermarket. 
I had to struggle with cutting the phyllo sheets and adjusting it in the pan.

country:
None
text:
Definitely a favorite! Per other reviews: roast (careful not to burn) walnuts before chopping, try the spray bottle method for the phyllo - melt butter, pour into a spray bottle (emptied I can't believe it's Butter) spray layers quickly. Changed my oven temp to 325. Add 1 t. lemon zest to honey mixture, don't cut all the way through while soaking in the sauce, wait till ready to remove from pan.  Make sauce and keep in fridge before baking baklava, it's better if 1 is cold and the other hot. Not so good if sauce and Baklava are both warm.

text:
I have never made Baklava before. I also have never rated a recipe before. I made 2 batches in one night because the first one although it tasted great, fell apart. Read as many positive reviews as you can and it will be a breeze! Some of the things I learned that I found most helpful: I put melted butter in a spray bottle. Worked GREAT! Set aside 8 sheets of phyllo dough ahead of time for the top layer. I added some sugar to the nuts.
I did make extra syrup and I made it first and then cooled completely so I could pour it on the hot baklava fresh from the oven. My greek boyfriend said he's never had better and his father said "Only my mother made it better". Thanks for this AWESOME recipe!!

text:
This was perfection!!! I did follow the changes suggested by others: 1. Made 1 1/2 the sauce and it was the perfect amount! 2. Made sauce early and let it cool before adding to the baklava. 3.Didn't cut the baklava all the way down until after the sauce cooled.  4.  Lightly buttered (someone said too much  butter would make it soggy). 5. Cooked it at 300- 325  and watched it until it was just browned on top. 6. I used walnuts, almonds, and pecans. It's pretty much the best dessert I've ever had and I have had a LOT of desserts. I've had baklava in Turkey and Greece and mine was just as good. Make this!!!! It's yummy!!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a double batch, what an edeavor!!!  
Since nuts are so expensive I used 1/4 # dates and 3/4# nuts (8 oz pecans, 6 oz pistachios, and 2 oz cashews), for the sauce I used raw honey, turbinado sugar, and zest from 2 lemons.  I 1.5x the sauce recipe and chilled it while I made and baked the pastry.  Next time will definitely try misting butter instead brushing, just have to figure a way to keep butter hot.  Phyllo can be very tricky to work with as it is so delicate if you let it get too dry it will crumble, rip and tear and too moist it sticks to other sheets.  Don't let it aggravate you, I go through and separate the sheets for each layer with plastic wrap before starting so I don't have to keep track of  how many sheets I have put down and can gauge how much filling I have for each layer.

text:
I tried this recipe and it was absolutely delicious. All you have to do is work fast and bake it for 40 minutes instead of 50 to get it to a nice golden crisp. For everyone who wrote bad comments about how this isn't real baklava, it is real. Baklava can be Arab or Greek. The Arab way does not have the cinnamon and  vanilla flavor in it. It also uses pistachios instead of walnuts. Baklava is NOT Turkish.

text:
WOW.  THIS WAS FANTASTIC. Two inexperienced bakers here (aka college kids) were able to pull this off with ease on the first try!   We followed the directions for the most part, but did create the sauce before anything else then chilled it in the fridge.  We also didn't cut all the way through before adding sauce.  Our nut mixture was 10oz of walnuts 6oz of almonds.  Make sure the phyllo dough is thawed out all the way before working with it, or it will crumble and flake apart.  We didn't use the damp towel.  Made 16 triangles.  Watching the video beforehand was helpful to.

text:
This is the first time I have ever made BAKLAVA. With everyone telling me how difficult fillo dough is to work with I was a little skeptical. It wasn't hard at all.   My tips:  Oven temp 530 degrees.  I put the BUTTER in a pampered chef spray bottle. This made spreading the butter EASY & FAST. I did NOT put a damp towel over the fillo dough, instead: I put a piece of wax paper in the FREEZER for about 10 minutes. I would put it on the fillo dough in between the time I was making my layers. YOU CAN DO THIS! Great recipe!

None
text:
I found this incredibly easy to make and it was a HUGE hit with family and friends!  Luckily I read a lot of the comments first and as a result I did find that I had to increase the butter to 3 sticks and then use a pastry brush to *paint* each layer.  I found that cutting it first made it cook more evenly.  Also the type of honey you use may add some flavor to the dish.  Lastly, with the second batch I got inventive and added mini chocolate chips to one end of the pan -- what made it taste just like the chocolate baklava I had in Istanbul!

userID:
1192567
Display Name:
DEBBIEDH
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3210610.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG!!! This was absolutely delicious and exactly how I remembered it growing up!  I used half walnuts and half pecans finely chopped in my food processor, which made this step so easy.  As others suggested, I added 2 T. sugar and 1/2 t. more cinnamon to the nut mixture. Others also suggested giving it a more honey flavor so I added 1/4 C. honey to the sauce.  I enjoy honey so this addition was a good one for me. If you are not a real honey fan, then you should not add the additional honey.  I refrigerated the sauce to cool it off before pouring it on the hot out-of-the-oven baklava.  After baking, the top phyllo layers were crispy and light - not soggy.  Before baking, I tried to cut only through most of the layers to the bottom of the pan before pouring the sauce over it - its hard to judge, but made the effort.  I did not toast the nuts-it tasted fabulous anyway. I baked only about 45 minutes - came out perfect.  My husband and daughter who are not baklava fans liked it.  My son and I LOVED it!  This is not a low calorie dish, remember, but it is absolutely worth making.  I ate 4 in two days - not a good idea for the waistline.  I froze the other half of the recipe as others suggested.  So delicious!!!

text:
This was delicious! I watched the video listed with this recipe and that helped me get a visual for the layering process. I recommend using real butter to brush the sheets-not margarine or Pam. The butter flavor really shines through and helps balance the sugar/honey. I used hazelnuts because they were cheap, and I couldn't taste them too much so I'm glad I didn't need to splurge on walnuts/pecans. Also-my phyllo sheets came out of their package pretty wrinkled and broken, I just did my best with it and it didn't affect the final product in any way. Great, fool proof recipe!

text:
Tastes just as baklava should. It's sweet, sticky, crispy, and decadent. I did not cut the pastry sheets, I just folded them onto themselves. The amount of butter listed is plenty. Do not saturate your sheets in butter or they will not crisp. Also, I suggest leaving the amount of syrup the same, or it will be sickeningly sweet. This took me about twenty minutes to assemble.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-01-23T11:11:59.51
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
6382336
Display Name:
gendee
isPro:

followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I chose this recipe to try, and I'm really glad I did.  I'm also glad I didn't read all the reviews before I made it, because I followed it as written and we love it! I've only had baklava as made by the Greek monastery near my home, and this is actually better in my opinion.  It's not quite as sticky sweet as the baklava we get from the monastery bakery.  I've never used phyllo before, and that was a bit of a nightmare.  I don't know if it was something I did or what, but many of the sheets on the inside of the rolls were coming apart.  I just plowed ahead and put the puzzle together and it came out fine.  I melted the butter because it made sense and only realized that the recipe didn't specifically state that after reading the reviews!  I watched the pan when the time got close to 40 minutes (the recipe does say ABOUT 50 min, after all) and I took it out at about 45 minutes - Perfect.  Don't have any idea why there is such a range of cooking times in the reviews - mine was still very pale until just before the 40 minute mark.  To our family the whole thing is perfect!

Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
1466388
Display Name:
MYSTRESS
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/152583.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a wonderful recipe. As soon as that sauce caramelized, i went ahead and dug in for that first slice. I went for another. I called the hubby to come down from his mancave to try it. He had 2 and was walking around with it, swaying his head like Stevie Wonder while moaning in yummy heaven. This was at around 2pm so it was just snacking. I did not digress too much from the recipe and it was perfect just as it is. In fact, it was just a minimal modification. I did not realize that I did not have vanilla extract until I was back from the store, so instead, I steeped half a cinnamon stick while simmering (yes, I know...if somebody asked me what I would more likely find in somebody's pantry, vanilla extract or cinnamon, I would say vanilla extract!) For the nuts, I used my left over walnuts and bought pecans to make the 1 pound. It was cheaper than the other nuts. I also followed Sandra lee's suggestion not to cut the Baklava all the way to the bottom to keep the sauce from spilling out and allowing it to seep through every nook and cranny. This is very easy to make. Brushing every other sheet of phyllo dough with butter was the most time consuming. As I logged in here to make this review, I saw that somebody suggested using a spray bottle to apply the butter. I have to remember to do that next time. Yes, there will definitely be a next time. And a next one. And a next one.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Count me among the people who thought there was a mystery behind making Baklava, and was too mystified to attempt making it myself. This recipe simplifies it and makes even the novices among us feel like Greek Baklava gods and godesses. I make the recipe as is, with the addition of a 1/2 tsp of ground cardamon in the nuts. It adds a "bright" flavor. To make the drudgery of of buttering the layers easier, I re-purposed an empty bottle of spray "margarine" to use as a butter sprayer. Every 2nd layer, I spritz the sheet down. Works likea charm--just the right amount of butter. Even if you're on the fence about making this version, I say go for it. It's quicker than you think, easier than you could guess, and tastes heavenly.

text:
This is an Amazing recipe, and is pretty easy. Like alot of others I melt the butter and brush it on the sheets of dough. I also start cooking the sauce before I start on the Baklava, when its done I put it in the refrigerator to cool. Then as soon as I take the Baklava out of the oven I pour on the now cooled honey sauce, this has always insured the Baklava is crunchy and not soggy. I have had so many complements people just love it the best complement I got was from someone saying, "The last time I had Baklava this good, I was in Italy"... it doesn't get better than that :)

text:
I tried the vegan version of this recipe, and it turned out perfectly, especially the syrup. 
I used 8 oz of walnuts and 4 oz of almonds and substituted Smart Balance for butter and agave syrup for honey. I only used 1/2 cup water to 1 cup agave (it might have been too much agave, since it's sweeter than honey). I also added a dash of nutmeg and clove, and 2 tsp of vanilla rather than 1. It was a huge hit at a family get-together and now they are requesting it for Christmas!

None
country:
None
text:
The Baklava came out great! I would definitely make it again - everyone raved about it at Easter! If you've never worked with Phyllo dough, note that you have to melt the butter first and then use a pastry brush to brush it on the layers.  Someone on the reviews said a spray bottle works well too.  Also, I forgot to thaw out my phyllo dough and instead had to work with broken dough and therefore had to piece it all together - but that made no difference to the texture or flavor - as far as I could tell.

text:
Wow!! Just made this (my family loves baklava/kadayif) and it is amazing! A lot of people were saying to increase the sauce a little bit, I doubled it and it ended up being too much - but this was forgivable. Also, pouring the cold sauce over the hot baklava or vice versa, was great as was turning the heat down to 325; the baklava was still crispy. It was second best (behind our favorite greek resturant!) and I have to say, I ate a whole row by myself (1x1 squares) and got yelled at by my mother XD. A great recipe - a total keeper!

Just made this last night for the Valentine potluck I'm a part of tonight.  I had a piece to test...which turned into another...and then a third.  Fantastic and way easier to make than one would think--as other reviewers have mentioned, it's just important to not let the dough dry out.  That was easily remedied with a damp paper towel.  I also had to take my pan out of the oven at around 45 minutes b/c I had to meet friends for dinner, but the baklava still turned out fine.

Display Name:
Bethany LeBlanc Harden
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/18.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow! Wow!! My first time making this and I followed Sandra Lee's suggestions about not using too much butter. Do not soak the sheets, just wet them. I tried some of her quick tips like using the whole phyllo sheet instead of cutting it, and also not covering the sheets between layers (time consuming) It turned out WONDERFUL!!!! I was so intimidated to make Baklava for so long, and now I wonder why I waited so long. You will love this!! I also read up on storage. If you like softer baklava with a liquidy texture (yum!) then store out of the refrigerator in a covered container. If you like it firm and chewy then store in the refrigerator. I am serving this in muffin cups for my husband to take to work. Of course, I kept some home for the family. Enjoy!!

text:
This is a great classic Baklava recipe. I used a mixtue of nuts - walnuts, almonds and macadamia - since I love any kind of nuts. I put some in my blender and chopped some by hand to have different textures of nuts. 2 things I did wrong - 1. I didn't butter my top 6 or 8 layers enough, so they separated from the nuts layers when I picked them up. 2. My honey mixture boiled over since I wasn't watching it. All in all, my baklava still came out perfect. DEF made the sauce ahead of time and let sit while the baklava is baking. I will use this recipe again around the holidays.

text:
WOW!! I don't care WHERE Baklava is originally from, it's prevalent all over the Mediterranean and Middle East...I wanted to learn to make Baklava for my husband, this recipe is IT! It is so easy-time consuming, esp my first time- but well worth it. I followed the recipe exactly except I folded over the sheets instead of cutting them in half. At the beginning I was buttering in between EVERY single half-sheet, but then I got nervous I read the directions wrong and switched to every 2 half-sheets. I don't think it made a big difference. I didn't even let the Baklava cool completely before I poured the syrup on. I did that right before bed and waited to try a piece til this morning, HEAVEN! Thanks Mtclross87, what a great recipe!
