text:
Just made for the first time and I think the recipe is a little misleading.  It sounds like you only use 16 sheets of the dough, ie...the two layers, butter, two layers, butter until you've done 8 sheets, then add some nuts, then two sheets, butter, nuts, two sheets, butter nuts until the top layer has 6-8 sheets.  Since mine is so thin I'm assuming I was supposed to continue layering until I had used all of the dough.  I didn't even use half the nuts and if I added all of the sauce it would be swimming in it.  I'll try adding more layers next time.

country:
None
text:
Not that this recipe needs another review, but I wanted to let people know a few quick little modifications that worked for me. The phyllo I had was about twice as big as the pan I was using, so I folded each sheet in half before putting it into the pan, then just buttered the top surface (resulting in butter between every *other* layer).  I also made this with only 8 ounces of pecans and it was quite tasty.  And finally, I added an ounce or so of orange blossom water to the syrup and I do think that added something to the flavor.  I did not use all the syrup, but maybe around 2/3 and that seemed like the right amount for me.  Tasty!!!

This recipe is fantastic!  If you spread thinner layers of butter between layers of phyllo dough you will get a crispier baklava. userID:
3602618
Display Name:
petunia
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/191902.jpg
city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the first time I've made baklava. I was pretty intimidated because I've always thought it would be such a difficult thing to make. This recipe surprised me! Although working with the filo dough was a struggle, the rest was easy. I only used half the filo dough (8oz) that the recipe calls for.  I used a mix of pecans and walnuts, which I chopped using a food processor.  This made the mixture so easy to use when I was doing the layering.  The 1 cup of butter was way too much, as I had about half of it left.  Those were the only changes I made, and it was awesome!! I had baklava at a restaurant last week, and this was much better!

text:
I am a novice at making baklava, but with this recipe you would never be able to tell!  It is absolutly delicious (and this is even an understatement!!) We did as another person suggested and cut it to within a half an inch from the bottom to allow the syrup to be absorbed in the upper layers instead of sinking to the bottom, then cut all the way through after it had cooled completely.  We also brushed the butter very lightly between EACH sheet of the phyllo dough.  Other than those 2 things, we followed the recipe to a "T".  Thank you for the great recipe!!

text:
After reading some reviews, I went a bit lighter on the butter and probably only used a half cup.  I think next time I may use 3/4 cup.  I ended up putting on an extra .5 recipe of the honey sauce to make the Baklava a little less dry.  

I think it really depends on how you like your Baklava - if you don't like it more dry, then use less butter and less sauce. If you enjoy a "soggier" Baklava, put on more butter and more sauce.  My family preferred the "soggier" version!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-11-09T21:02:21.543
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
805040
Display Name:
Julie
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
13
favoritesCount:
34
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am not new to cooking in general but this was my first attempt with phyllo.  I had to bring a few things to a greek themed dinner party.  I followed several suggestions including 1 and a half times the syrup - added a cinnamon stick and let it simmer two hours and used a spritzer bottle to get the butter on the sheets.

Everything went great except two operator errors.  I hate over chopped nuts so I carefully chopped my pecans so they would not turn to dust.  That was a mistake - they need to be WELL chopped.  Next time I will use my handy chopper and will let it go to town.

The second error was that I did not use enough butter.  That spritzer made that butter go a very long way - I probably only used 1/4 cup.  It was quick and handy but between my pecans being too large and my sheets not getting gooey enough - the baklava did not stick together correctly.  

Even with my goofs, they were beautiful and all 8 adults ate theirs and complimented them - and the hosts teen aged son came back to get them over and over until they were almost all gone.

This is a remarkably good recipe.

text:
This was my first time making baklava, and I'm so glad it was easy.  I strongly recommend using walnut chips rather than chopped nuts.  Chopped nuts are too big for this recipe.  Also, I used slightly less butter to cut down on any sogginess (another reviewer was right when they said it was the butter and not the sauce that causes sogginess).  I have yet to see how this will taste when left overnight.

text:
This crisps very easily, so watch out! You want it nice and gooey! Also (although, much to my annoyance, I only read this after I made the baklava!), it's a great idea to cut the pastry into correct-sized pieces before starting - you can work a lot faster and get it in the oven in half the time!

text:
My husband LOVES baklava and I promised to make him some.  I found this recipe and decided to conquer my fear of phyllo.  I made it just in time for the Super Bowl party we had to go to and it was a H-I-T.  I had people I don't even know seeking me out to gush about how yummy it is!  

Because I was trying to make the party, I didn't let my dough thaw fully so it crumbled into pieces. I just pulled out what I needed to make the layers and went with it.  It was no problem.  The baklava still came out beauifully.  

I am back for the recipe with the first part safely in the oven. (that part's not hard) I did let my dough thaw before using it this time and it was much easier to work with!  (and I didn't let it sit so long that it was sticky.)

Can't wait for this batch to come out of the oven!

I made this last night for my New Year's Eve party and it was a big hit! It was flaky and crisp on top, soft and moist (without being gooey) on the inside. The only thing I did different was make the sauce while I was assembling the baklava, that way the sauce was cool when I poured it over the hot baklava. I will be making this for years to come. Thanks!

text:
So good!  I read and am thankful for all the reviews.  I used 1 1/2 times the syrup as recommended and also poured it cooled onto hot baklava.  I toasted the nuts and used mostly walnuts and a few almonds.  I bought a new silicone pastry brush to apply the melted butter (ended up using 3 sticks) and it worked great.  I also tried a pizza cutter for slicing but thought the knife worked just about as well.  The baklava takes a while to put together, but is not difficult.  Totally worth the time and effort.  Thanks!

This was fantastic.  I'll admit that I was a little intimidated to try this as I have never worked with Phyllo before and heard nightmares.  This was a breeze (albeit time consuming) and absolutely fantastic!  I have a family member from Greece who makes this for us and this is every bit as good (or betther) than hers!
I followed the recipe exactly and took others' advice to make the syrup first and let cool before pouring over the hot baklava.  It remained crispy on top even the next day! My in laws love baklava and went crazy for this recipe.

I will make often.  Thanks for sharing!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I only made half the recipe, since I was only cooking for two. I had no honey, used heavy cream in place of the honey, and loved it! Made is more savory and less sweet, since baklava often overdoes on the sweetness. I also skipped nuts, my husband has an allergy. Use cinnamon and nutmeg, and use unsalted butter. Last 5 minutes of baking I sliced a banana on top, was wonderful. Drizzled the sugar/water/milk/vanilla over the hot baklava...absolutely delicious!

text:
Very easy to make, and tastes WAY better than what most stores sell.  I ground pistachios with a mortar and pestel for the topping (placed on after baking) and used almonds, hazelnuts, and fancy pecans as filler.  Cut the pieces before I baked, and made sure the sugar mixture was cool before topping the baklava right out of the oven.

Definitely a keeper!!

text:
Wow, if I had known baklava was this easy to make, I would've been making it years ago.  I'm no expert pastry cook, and the phyllo was not very forgiving - but the taste was just as good as the expensive baklava you get at the bakery.

One review suggested cooking the sugar/honey mixture first.  But with the baklava baking for 50 minutes; I found that was enough time to boil sugar and water and simmer with the honey and vanilla for 20 minutes.

FABULOUS!  EASY!!!
tips:
1) spray bottle of butter mentioned by another reviewer makes buttering the phyllo much easier, and requires much less butter than recipe calls for
2)  make syrup first and let cool as others have suggested
3) i only used 3/4 of phyllo because my stack was getting really high, and it was still really good

text:
I learned to make bakalava many years ago from a Turkish boyfriend.  He made it similar than this, but used only sugar and water for the syrup, and no cinnamon.  I made it that way for years, and then I tried this recipe.  This recipe is good, but I think I like it better the original way I learned to make it.  Simpler flavor, but very rich as well.  Also, my friend said it was imperative to use pistachios for the nuts, and I always do.  This recipe is delicious though.

text:
This recipe is good, although I sprinkled cinnamon sugar between the layers w/butter, added 1/2 cup sugar to the nut mixture and added 1/2 cup more honey, water and sugar to the sauce, poured the hot sauce over the hot baklava and let set overnight on top of the stove uncovered. It was great, there was plenty of gooey sauce and it soaked into the layers.(If you prefer a less sweet version leave out the extra sugar in the nuts and between the layers) Yummy!

The recipe makes for very sweet baklava. I recommend adjusting it according to your taste. However, it turned out beautiful and delicious. I brought it to a cooking club and everyone was raving about how it looked and tasted like it was from a Greek bakery! It's also pretty labor-intensive, with the multiple layers and additional care one has to take when working with phyllo. Overall, it was worth it. Oh, also, I added other kinda of nuts including my fave pistachios. Yum!

I made baklava for the first time and they came out great.  It did take a long time to chop the nuts. text:
I made this for my bf's birthday and this recipe is AWESOME! It is very, very easy. This was my first time making baklava, and also my first time working with phyllo. I was nervous because I read some horror stories about how hard it was and one recipe I read said they recommended not even attempting it, just buy it. But I'm stubborn and no matter what anybody said I was making it :) . My bf and I did it together and it came out wonderful. This Baklava is not for someone who likes it very sweet, like me, but I was told I have a sweet tooth that could kill an elephant. Everybody loved it and they loved that it wasn't as sweet. 
My sauce for the top was about the consistency of water, maybe a little thicker. I don't know if it was supposed to be thicker or what so that had me nervous. Anyway it is great! Thanks for a wonderful recipe!!!

text:
Wow. This recipe is definately a keeper. I am very impressed. I never thought that I could make Baklava, but this recipe proved me wrong. I used melted butter and applied to the sheets with a pastry brush- I used about 1.5 cups of butter. I like the idea of pulverizing the nuts in a food processor first- I may do that next time. The honey sauce is fabulous. I used salted butter, and it was perfect- it gave it a lot of extra flavor. Mmmmm.... Baklava. Mmmmmm...

text:
I held a Greek dinner party last week, and this was one of the sweets - a huge success.   One thing to warn English cooks about - it is better to use UNSALTED butter, rather than the salted we usually use in England. I never found out if it freezes well - all left overs were demolished by my grandsons when they came next day!

text:
I have eaten lots of Baklava and watched my father make it before, but never made it myself. I have to say, this recipe nails it! I added a little rose water to the honey mixture because I heard that makes it better. It was great, I took half the batch to a clients house and left the other half for my roommates, who stopped me dead in my tracks next time they saw me and told me it was the best thing they have ever eaten in their life. I just grinned. If you want a classic and delicious baklava, this is the one. Oh yeah, I was a little heavy on the butter, i ran out and had to melt more. Don't get the phyllo soaked with butter, the honey mix will do the honors on that.

text:
I made this exactly as written and it was great. I melted the butter and used a pastry brush. I also ground up walnuts in my grandma's old nut grinder (dump the nuts in the plastic top, crank the handle till they all end up in the glass jar below) and the texture was terrific. I've always struggled with phyllo dough - it always seems to stick together, but this time I used the Safeway Select brand and it worked perfectly.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was good, but not great.  

First, I used toasted nuts (pistachios), which was a mistake because they were over-toasted at the end.  I would use raw nuts in the future and see how that turns it.

The baklava were soggy, so I would incorporate the suggestions of other to pour warm syrup on cooler baklava and then put immediately on individual serving papers (paper cupcake cups)

My phyllo ended up overly browned, so I would watch it more carefully if I were to make it again.

I changed the number of layer of phyllo per the suggestions of others and that worked well.

Despite my issues with this receipe, my husband and father were impressed.

city:

country:
None
text:
This recipie worked out great.  The first time I tried it I did not have the almonds available so I made it with chopped apples, and this was also amazing.  I added 1 cup honey instead of 1/2 cup to thicken the sauce a bit because the apples will provide more liquid.  Cook times were almost the same, possibly a bit longer.  When making the nut variety, the 1 pound of nuts may be a bit much.  Don't forget to apply the butter and to cut the dish before baking.  I have made this dish several times and the cuts are esential before baking; I found out the hard way.

This desert were great with an italian meal, but I eventually hope to try it with a Greek dish.

text:
I haven't made this in about 25 years.  This is a great recipe and will be making it again very soon.  It is time consuming,  but so worth it!  I had some issues with the Filo but mainly because I was in a rush and my Filo dough was not completely thawed.  Always best to plan ahead and have everything ready.  However, little rips in the dough aside, it turned out awesome!  I took some to a dinner party and they were gobbled up so fast!   I used walnuts but not the full amount listed in the recipe.  And pouring the honey mixture over the baklava right after it came out of the oven was crazy; it was sizzling and steaming and I thought, this is too much liquid!  But I poured the whole amount all over the 9 x 11 pan and it just absorbed!  So yummy!  I think it will go smoother next time, will plan ahead to allow my dough to thaw!

userID:
6256836
Display Name:
yummyinmytummy
isPro:
False
followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/551673.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve made this 3 times now over the years and as I just finished the last piece after making this last batch over two weeks ago, I have come to appreciate how this baklava only gets better with age. I made it the day before Christmas and it was very good fresh and after guests left I was left with still quite a few pieces. I was worried how to store it properly, so it sat out another day then I moved it to the fridge for about a week while continuing to munch on it. Even in the fridge they were still crispy on the tops and bottoms and the center was moist and slightly chewy. So good. When I ran out of room in the fridge I just sat it back out on the counter for almost another week until while I slowly made it disappear.  The first two times I made it exactly as written but with pecans. These turned out great and I took them to work on a few separate pot luck occasions where everyone raved about it. This Christmas batch I wanted to try different things and ended up using tips from several reviewers on here and I also used a few from the Athena brand phillo dough, which is the brand I used. I used a 1lb package of slivered almonds that I toasted first, added maybe 1/4 to 1/2 cup homemade brown sugar, (from this site) zest of one lemon and a pinch of cloves to the nut mixture. I found that not cutting clear through to the bottom but stopping about 1/2” above kept the sugar liquid from pooling at the bottom therefore there was no need to make a double batch of that. Excellent!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making Baklava for Christmas for 30 years.  One of my family's favorites!  A couple tips.  Don't chop the nuts too fine.  If you do, the baklava will have sandy texture.   I use about 1.5-2 lb mix of pecans, almonds and walnuts.   

I add about 1/4 sugar to the nuts.  I also add about 1/8 teaspoon of finely ground clove or I'll add a whole clove to the sauce and remove before I pour over the baklava.  Finally, I add a bit of lemon zest or teaspoon of lemon juice to the sauce.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made it several times, using the "I Can't Believe It's Not Butter" sprayer. Uses less butter [fewer calories...as if we care when eating baklava...] and provides easier application of the butter. I keep the sprayer in hot water to keep the butter liquid. Placing newspaper around the baking dish helps catch overspray. Avoid cutting to the bottom of the pan until after it is baked!
 I like this recipe because it's not too sweet, but I'm going to experiment to achieve more of a honey flavor than this recipe yields.

My son asks for this for his birthday every year (use to be cheesecake) now I make the day before I am not great at following directions so I am glad this is forgiving as far as phyllo is considered.. A rip here or there no big deal is is covered and a wrinkle no big deal. I can never get the cutting  down where you do not go all the way through but no one complains.. I have used walnuts each time but this year is will be different maybe pistachios My son loves them so why not. I never cover the sheets I find that the hardest part. I move fast. Others have said they but the "I cant believe it not butter" and use the bottle. I think I will just but a small spray bottle instead.. it is the best Baklava I have ever made and my son loves it.. Thanks for the recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Holy cow, I love this recipe! I did follow the advice of a couple other reviews and tweaked it just a bit. I bumped the sugar sauce up to 1 1/2 times the recipe. I used two sticks of butter rather than one.  I pulsed my walnuts in a food processor rather than chopping them. I also used a really great tip from another reviewer. I emptied out a bottle of I Can’t Believe it’s Not Butter spray into a bowl and put my melted butter into the spray bottle. Spraying the butter on rather than brushing it made assembly super quick and easy.  Once I was finished, I just refilled it with the spray butter.  It turned out so wonderful!  I will definitely be making this many more times.

I’ve made this recipe three times now, and it’s always a huge hit. text:
I have been on a quest for the best baklava I can find/make and this recipe is great! I do use 1 cup honey  and 1/2 cup of sugar instead. Also, tip for the phyllo dough, keep your house cold and dry and work fast. Make sure your other ingredients are ready before you take the phyllo dough out of the refrigerator and set up an assembly line to put it all together. I also make the butter almost melted so it spreads quick with minimal issues with the phyllo dough. It's not as scary to make as people think!

text:
I've been making this for years but never rated it.  My daughter's Lebanese graduate classmates were shocked that an American made the closest to their own country's  dessert they'd ever tasted!  As others did, I increased the sauce by 50% and made it a day earlier so to cool if thoroughly.  It's imperative to add the cool sauce immediately after removing the hot dish from the oven.  If not, allow the dessert to cool completely and then pour on very hot liquid mixture.  This wonderful dish occupies a page in my family's traditional recipe book.  Thank you for your recipe and all the reviews!  Oh, SO important is the type of honey!  My favorite is wildflower, followed by clover.  I've tried others but strongly recommend those two.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this as my first ever attempt at baklava. I modified this to be nut-free since we have serious tree nut allergies in the family. I cleaned the flesh off of butternut squash and pumpkin seeds, then dried them and tossed them in a little olive oil and a pinch of salt. I spread them out on a sheet lined with parchment paper and put them in the oven on 275F. I actually did these seeds separately on different days for my own convenience, so the smaller butternut squash seeds were ready in about 13 minutes, whereas the pumpkin seeds needed closer to 20 minutes. I also added a few sunflower seeds since I had them and chopped everything making a good 1 cup portion. I was incredibly pleased with how these turned out! It was definitely a labor of love with the additional steps of scooping out seeds and roasting them, but it was worth it to have this treat in our home! You could always use your favorite commercially prepared roasted seeds. 

I myself have no food allergies, so I have eaten traditional baklava many times and can honestly report that the switch to seeds does not really impact the taste or texture of this dessert. It's the dough and the syrup that are the true backbone here! 

Excellent recipe. At one time, I would have found the idea of making my own baklava intimidating, but this recipe made it very accessible.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-10-21T02:12:21.11

city:

text:
I’ve made it twice. Both times I did not  use even close to the amount of butter - and ended up with delicious, not-soggy baklava. I sprinkled nuts more frequently between the layers than recipe said. Otherwise I would have had too much left at the end. Update: made it 4 times. I use 3/4 cup butter, 4 cups chopped nuts (pistachios, almonds, walnuts, pea cans). Don’t rush the phyllo dough thawing process, and don’t let it sit open or it will dry and break up.

text:
This recipe was outstanding in so many ways. Having never made baklava before I was anxious about working with phyllo dough. But if you follow the directions on the box, I used Athens, it was a breeze. And I followed these 2 tips others have written 1. roast the nuts - I used walnuts and almonds and 2. make  1 1/2 cups of sauce. I did add 1/4 tsp. of ground cloves & 2 tsps. of granulated sugar to the nuts after roasting. I also added 3 large strips of lemon skin, 1 cinnamon stick, 5 whole cloves & 1/4 tsp of salt to the sauce along with the other ingredients.  This added so much flavor. It baked perfectly at 350 for 50 minutes in the bottom third of the oven;  but I’m sure it varies based on your oven.  It was a hit at the dinner party and not a crumb left on the plate. Wonderful recipe and it is now in my keeper file!

text:
This was my first time making baklava. We usually order a 9x13 tray from a local bakery. I am so happy I tried this recipe. I followed the recipe exact. I didn't have any issues. The baklava wasn't as sweet as the store bought but that's a great thing it was just right! I used the no name brand called select from my local jewel osco store. I also did cut the phyllo in half it fit perfectly that way. It turned out the perfect color and crunchy ! I am not a cook or baker so I am very pleased with how easy this recipe was.    The only issue I had was when I was cutting the dough it would move alot but don't worry about that because ones it's baked and your pour your sauce on it's not noticeable and the top layer can be flaked off if you need.    I also probably put a few extra layers on top as I had extra sheets and it worked out well  :) my hubby told me to make tea tonight because he is excited to try the baklava !

text:
I had never made or even tasted Baklava and never worked with fillo dough. My wife likes it so I thought I'd give it a shot. The only change I made was to make the sauce first and refrigerate it while I put the baklava together and baked it. Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly. I tried it shortly after I made it and found it to be dry. The next day was very different, the sauce had found it's way all the way through and was moist but not soggy. What a difference a day makes. I had people who have had baklava critique it, only to tell me it's perfect. Excellent recipe, thanks to the author.   : )

text:
I've made this exactly as it said many times and it always turns out great. Everyone's mouths' water when I bring this out to eat at any occasion and they think I am a master chef for it. I've met very few people who do not like baklava and it is usually due to a distaste for honey......but if you like honey even a little bit make this to see just how good it can be. It is the one of the greatest desert I've ever tasted and we have a few true chefs in my family who agree. Do yourself a favor and make this recipe you will be surprised.....and feel free to drizzle some melted chocolate over the squares in the morning.

Easy peazy.  Followed some of the more popular reviews and all went fine. Made the sugar/water mixture first and put it in the fridge.  Ground the mixed nuts in the food processor - just pulse smaller quantities until you reach the consistency you want.  Tasty and surprisingly easy to make. The effort is really just all the prep. Will absolutely make it again.

text:
I've been making this for many years now and it hasn't failed me yet.  It's absolutely perfect! 
Crisp, buttery layers with the sweet taste of honey.  Mmmm!  The recipe does not state the kind of nuts to use, but I prefer walnuts.   I've also found that it works best to make the honey sauce first and set aside.   This bakes faster than you think.  The bake time says 50 min., but mine is usually crisp and golden brown in about 35 - 40 minutes.

I NEED MORE STARS. This is DELICIOUS!!! A couple things: I used pecans for the nuts. To save time on chopping I put a cup or so at a time in my blender and pulse a few times until it was crumb-sized. Not a powder, but small pieces for sure. Also, this was my first time using fillo dough, and they're not kidding when they say to use a damp cloth. NOT damp paper towels, ya'll. RIP, three sheets of fillo.

text:
I made this today for the first time. As a newbie, I made some mistakes. However, even with the mistakes, it was delicious! Husband and coworkers said it was best they ever had and that was with mistakes. So, learn from my mistake. 1. Don’t forget to cut it prior to baking. I had to cut it after and it made them not so pretty. 2. Make sure you have nuts. I only had pecans so I put them in a freezer bag and pounded them down but tasted great. 3. Make sure you have cinnamon. I didn’t have any cinnamon but I did have apple pie seasoning and it tasted good. 4. I only had 3/4 C white sugar so I added 1/4 brown sugar to equal the 1 C needed.

text:
I have made this recipe last week and my friends loved it. I made it again today but added shredded cooked jackfruit in the second layer in between the first and last layers. Jackfruit is an asian fruit , you can buy them in asian markets in can. I drained the liquid and used this liquid as part of the syrup. I used two or three pieces and shredded them and cooked them in the same liquid about half a cup of jackfruit syrup  till they are soft. cooked and tender. Delicious! I will call it  Persian Baklava with Asian twist LOL!

text:
This was definitely an easy-to-prepare dessert. I used a 7x11 baking dish and so a single phyllo sheet folded in half fit perfectly (adjust baking time to 35-40 mins). I added a bit of nutmeg to the nuts along with the cinnamon (as per a review I read). Also 1.5x the sauce, and added cold as per reviews. It's a rich dish, very sweet, and unless you can find nuts for cheap, is also expensive. I bought from bulk bins, and on sale, and still spend $20 just on nuts.

None
text:
Great recipe! Was a bit time consuming, but overall easy to make. Just a couple suggestions:
-Set the timer for 30 or 40 minutes instead of 50. You may not need the whole time.
-The video recommends putting a damp cloth over the phyllo dough to keep it from drying out. Be careful with this, as the cloth stuck to the dough and ruined the top two sheets.
-I used walnuts, pistachios, and almonds for the nut mixture.  The recipe doesn't specify, but this mixture turned out great!

This turned out so well!! My ESL students loved it, as did my dad and husband. I found it pretty simple to make and i didn't find it as time-consuming as everyone warned me it would be to make. I'm thankful I tried it. I will definitely do it again. I used walnuts for mine. I will say that I baked a 9x13 first then used smaller Pyrex pans (? Maybe 4x7 or so) for the others. It did not bake as well in the smaller ones and because I didn't realize it wouldn't, I baked for the full amount of time l, which burned them. Definitely stick to the 9x13 or else watch it closer for cooking time adjustments. This was great, though!

userID:
20428012
Display Name:
Rebecca Dougherty
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3944154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is my go to recipe... no matter what site I visit or even the recipe that is on the Phyllo dough box, the various ingredients used are the same except for the spices! So its a matter of taste.                                                                                  According to a family member when traveling in Greece , Honey that is scented with orange flowers is added depending on the island or mainland. Honey is used as a preservative and to withstand the heat of the out door market stall. The honey syrup used here I scented with grated orange/tangerine rind. I made the syrup first and cooked until thickened and reduced by a third.  Take off heat and  cool.                                                                                                       I do recommend to score all the way through to the bottom.  Once the pastry is out of the oven and before it is cooled... spoon your syrup over the baklava... you'll hear a sizzle!! only spoon enough over the pastry until the sizzling has stopped and each triangle is covered and glistening! You will not used all of the syrup. Store remaining syrup in a mason jar and refrigerate. Use it over french toast! Or sticky buns!  Enjoy...
Review:
Rating:
5

userID:
20636341
Display Name:
Mary Bee
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is WONDERFUL. It's not too sweet and has plenty of room for variation. Speaking of variation, here's what I did:
Instead of expensive blanched almonds ($9.99/lb!) I used 1/2 lb. sunflower seeds and 1/2 lb. chopped walnuts. As for the butter, I only needed less than one stick, so less than half a cup. SO glad I didn't pre-melt that second stick of butter. I also ended up only having to cook the baklava for about half an hour, and I think it's because I used a metal pan instead of glass. The top is crispy and flaky and the bottom is holding together. Given the chance, I'd probably leave it in for a little longer, but I'm happy with how it turned out. I added a tiny bit of lemon juice to the syrup and am pleased with the results. Last but not least, I followed some advice another user posted on here about only cutting the baklava 3/4 of the way down and cutting the rest after it was out of the oven. I do not have the magic touch so this DID NOT WORK FOR ME. It was really difficult to cut the baked baklava IN the pan, but also difficult to transport it FROM the pan and THEN cut it. Luckily I had plenty of time to go slow and make sure I didn't make a mess of things. 

Also, definitely serve in cupcake papers. Definitely.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-10-12T14:32:25.257

text:
So, my friend was throwing a Greek party and I wanted to keep with the theme and bring a Greek dish.  I have always wanted to make baklava but it just sounded complicated.  I had a box of phyllo dough in the freezer so I decided to just go for it.  This recipe had a ton of 5 star reviews, so I went with it.  I used walnuts but I'd like to try this with pecans, too.  It was SO easy to make; I can't believe I waited so long to make it!  Seriously, the hardest part was waiting for it to cool down so I could try a piece!    I prepared this EXACTLY as the recipe is shown but since I wasn't sure how it would turn out, I halved the recipe.  Next time I will not be halving the recipe.  This is seriously such an amazing dessert.  The party guests were impressed and my family enjoyed it , too. I literally ate it until I was sick.  The honey vanilla sauce you pour on top is to die for.  I will be making this over and over again.  Thank you for such a keeper of a recipe!  FIVE stars all the way!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. Very fast and simple. I did make a several slight changes though. Most important to make syrup first. In cooking time it only needed 40mins instead of the 50. I also used half a lemon instead of  vanilla for the syrup. 1cup sugar, 1cup water, 1cup orange blossom honey,  squeeze 1half of fresh lemon into pot. Simmer  on low heat for 20 to 30 mins let cool completely before you spoon onto baklava. You may not need all of the syrup it is very sweet. Remove baklava immediately  1min after you add syrup, it will stay crisp. I did need more butter than called for, i used half unsalted butter and half  al ghazal vegetable  ghee which you can find at any arab foods market, I also used half a pound walnuts with half pound pecans and two teaspoons of cinnamon for filling. It was unbelievably  yummm!

text:
I made this for a party two days ago and it was the hit of the party.  I've been told that I now have to make it for every party from now on!  Several people told me it was the best they'd ever tasted. I used walnuts, almonds, and a handful of pecans, chopped finely in a good processor. I mixed in 1/3 cup granulated sugar, 1 1/2 T cinnamon, and a dash each of nutmeg and cardamom. I followed the advice of other reviewers and made the syrup first (I added a bit of lemon zest to it) and chilled it, pouring it over the baklava right after taking it out of the oven. I will definitely be making this often!

I listened to the top reviews.  I made sure to lay the phyllo sheets out wrinkly for extra crunch.  I added the vanilla after I finished simmering the syrup, so the flavoring would not boil off.  I found that I needed to use about 4 Tablespoons (1/4 cup) of nut mixture per layer to use it up before I ran out of phyllo dough.  I also listened to the many reviews that said that you should chill the syrup and pour it over the hot baklava.  It sizzled when I poured it and turned out super crispy!

text:
Great and simple recipe for baklava!  I followed all the preparation and cooking directions for this recipe, but added my own twist by making "baklava fingers" instead.  Everything worked out the same.  I followed others' advice and made the sauce ahead of time and let it cool before pouring.   Also, after being soaked in the sauce, I reccommend letting each piece of baklava sit to drain by placing them along the rim of a large plate.   These two ideas will keep them from getting too soggy.

text:
Bak-lavaaaa youu~~~!!!
This recipe was amazing! 
I added 2 tbsp of lemon juice to the sauce along with the sugar and water which added a great tangy flavor that balances out the sweetness! I made it while the baklava was baking, so I placed the finished sauce in the refrigerator for about 10 minutes to accelerate the cooling process, and then proceeded to pour. I didn't have any honey, so I used brown rice syrup which worked just fine! 
I used a 9x9 pan so I only used one roll of the filo pastry, and was leftover with about a cup extra of ground nuts! I did use them to make some gf chocolate chips right after... :)

Super delicious recipe! Use partly pistachio cause its the best nuts! I have some butter left towards the end and i just pour them on top so it created like la layer of goodness. Make sure to put them in freezer while waiting for the oven to heat up just so the butter get more solid and the dough will be more crustier. I also left the sauce to boil a bit longer until it is not liquid but more syrup-py and really thick. It helps in not making your baklava soggy and still crispy at the bottom, trust me. Made 3 times so far, getting better every time. Recommended!!

text:
I am not a baker by any means. I asked my boyfriend what his favorite dessert was and he instantly said "baklava".. I thought I was doomed. But, alas this recipe turned out to be quite a hit. He LOVED it!  I had no trouble at all and found it to be easy.  Make the topping sauce first and store in fridge.
Definately use the towels to keep filo moist, dont stress about filo not being perfect. My layering went 1 sheet, butter, 2nd sheet, butter, till 4 deep. Then mixture, 1 sheet, butter, 2nd sheet, butter, mixture.. Untill i had 4 mixture layers and then I did 8 top layers buttering between each. Be sure to lightly butter every time, no need for drenching, just a light brush ( i used a new mini sponge paint roller).  Pre cut before baking and dont go all the way to the bottom. Bake time is spot on, and immediatly pour sauce right out of the oven, let cool, finish cut's to the bottom and remove from pan. I put mine in cupcake papers and kept them on the counter covered with a clean, dry dish towel. Boyfriend gobbled them up and was so touched that I aced the perfect baklava. Cheers!

userID:
16340602
Display Name:
Christine Saqui
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2589016.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an immediate hit at a recent retirement party.  First time I made it and it looked like a professional made it or that I inherited the recipe from some great grandma.  I almost had people believing that I was Greek (and I totally don't look it.  Lol).  
I took the time to read through the top reviews and tweeked the recipe accordingly.  Here are the tips that really helped (thanks guys!):
1. Make the sauce first, cool it down.  I was in a hurry so I stuck it in the fridge.  
2. Toast the nuts (I did it after I crushed it in the food processor)
3.  Add lemon zest to the sugar/water as it's boiling (1 lemon... smells so fragrant!)
4.  Don't soak the phyllo with butter, just lightly brush (using a rubber/silicone brush works great, plus no lost fibers from using a paint brush), let the phyllo get wrinkles
5.  Don't cut the phyllo in half, just keep folding it in half as you go.  And since it makes it go faster, no need to cover the rest with a damp cloth.
6. Before baking, don't cut all the way through the dough layers!  The sauce then collects between the bottom layers.  Cut all the way through after the sauce sets.
7.  Cook at 325 for first 40 minutes more or less, then at 350 to brown the top (last 10 minutes).  My oven seems to be on the hot side though.  But I'd definitely watch the browning since the phyllo cooks so easily.
8.  I tried pistachios, walnuts, and almonds.
9.  Increase the sauce by 1/2 more.  I noticed the baklava at one of my favorite restaurants was
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

userID:
16297409
Display Name:
Adi
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made Baklava several times over the years, and each time I don't remember what I did right/wrong so this time I am sharing.  When you google recipes for Baklava you will be surprised how many have twice the amount of butter or half the amount of walnuts as this recipe.  But I made this one because of the number of good reviews and I realized that it will turn out good however you make it, because Baklava is just good.  Based on reviews I decreased the temp to 325, which was a mistake.  The correct temp is 350 and I had to turn it up to get a golden crust.  The walnuts should be chopped very fine, otherwise the larger pieces will cause the layers to separate.  Maybe pulse on a food processer next time. Using 2 - 3 tbls of walnuts in between the layers is right even though it may seem sparse, you will have enough walnuts for all the layers.  Only lightly butter between each layer, 40 sheets of filo is 20 layers, 1 lb of butter is 16 tblsp, so use a little less than 1 tblsp between sheets.  I kindof drizzled the butter with my pastry brush.  Cut all the way thru before baking because it is difficult to cut afterwards.  I'm not sure if you need to use 1.5 times the sauce, I did that but didn't use it all, and the results were awesome.  I think pressing the whole thing down before baking might be a good idea next time.  This is really a great dessert and everyone is amazed you made Baklava.

Display Name:
rmc

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had some amazing baklava in Olympia when I was in Greece just over a month ago and had a craving so had to try to make it.  This recipe was really quite easy and delicious.  I didn't need to cover the dough as that took up more time than just layering and buttering quickly.  I made 1 1/2 times the sauce with the extra of honey and less water, orange and lemon peel and the sugar with the toasted nuts as other reviewers suggested.  
I have a hint that might help everyone.  The baklava that I bought in Greece had cloves stuck into the top surface.  It made it very pretty, added great flavor and made cutting the baklava super easy as it held the top sheets in place.  Just stick the whole cloves in the pastry so one will be in the center of each piece when cut.  I did also freeze for 15 minutes before cutting half way through and baking.

None
text:
I made baklava for the first time with this recipe, and a came out so well! I used half measures of the ingredients, since I was making it for a smaller party. Some tips to emphasize:
1) Melt the butter beforehand, and use a pastry brush to spread it on the dough. I first used a teaspoon to target general areas of dough, and the used the brush to spread it around.
2) Before you put your layers in the oven, be sure to cut the dough. I made it into squares with solid success.
3) This makes a lot of baklava. I made 24 squares even with half the recommended measures.

text:
This is a really good recipe! I followed the advice of other reviewers and it came out perfect the first time I made it. I used 3/4 cup water instead of 1 cup so the syrup would be thicker, and I also made the syrup before I even started the baklava so it would have time to cool to avoid sogginess. I also sprinkled finely ground nuts on top of it as a garnish (after baking) and used pecans which were tasty!

text:
The kids and my sisters went crazy for this dessert..I couldn't even let it cool and the kids were begging me to give them a piece . I made with walnuts and pecans and made exactly as written .  I did  not know how many layers to do so I ended up with a few extra phyllo sheets so I made rolled ones and bake separate. I cut the rolls into angles before I baked and they turned out perfect and beautiful on my cookie tray.with the layered batch, I did find my top layer ripping when I cut my squares and was a bit frustrated so for next time , I will definitely roll them and than cut them into angles,Way easier and much nicer.

country:
None
text:
Just made this for Christmas and got rave reviews. Angela's tip about spraying the butter on was genius.  I was able to work so fast I didn't even have to cover the dough.  I made the syrup as indicated rather than making 1 1/2 times the recipe as some suggested and it was plenty.  Any more and it would have been so soggy it would have been difficult to eat.  I also followed Elena's suggestion to make the syrup first and let it cool then pour the cooled syrup over the hot baklava.  The phyllo remained crisp and the syrup was evenly distributed.  All in all, an easy and tasty recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/973954.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was time consuming, but didn't require too many ingredients, which is a plus. I personally thought it was too sweet, and I don't know why, but without being refrigerated, it was soggy, which made the phyllo lose its crisp. The family really liked it though, and I think it had a pretty good flavor, aside from being really sweet.
Thanks for the recipe. I think I'll try it again :)

Tips:
*Use melted butter for the layers
*Lemon zest would really help the syrup..It needs something fruity to take away from the sugary sweetness
*Serve it refrigerated. At room temp, before being refrigerated (several hours after being baked), the phyllo would fall apart from the nut mixture when I tried to pick it up, and the sauce made it soggy and sticky. The refrigerator firmed it up 
*Make sure to use a LIGHTLY damp cloth for covering the dough as you work. Originally,the cloth I used was too damp, and it made the sheets stick together.

Display Name:
sam_I_am
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super recipe, and great results my first time out. Like the other reviews suggested, I made an extra half syrup recipe, used a food processor for the nuts, added 1/8 tsp clove and some sugar to the nut mixture, and used a spray bottle for the melted butter. This last tip helped me cut the butter by half, and believe me, I covered each layer with butter. Cooling before slicing helped, as did chilling the syrup. Very tasty recipe, labor intensive, but worth it. Resist the temptation to use more than a few tablespoons of nut mixture per layer. I thought the first few nut layers looked to sparse, so I added another TB or two. This made the layer too nutty when baked. As I started to run short on the nuts and made the last 5 layers or so with the recommended 2-3 TB of nuts per layer, it produced a much lighter and enjoyable result. So in short, don't overload the nuts!

text:
Best Baklava ever!!! I got so many compliments, with many saying the best they ever had. I used the suggestions from other reviews by preparing the sauce first and putting it in the fridge and adding more sugar. I also layered every 2-3 sheets using about 2tb per layer. I added a half cup more nuts, and melted the butter. I actually had about a half cup left over because I didn't want soggy dough. I was worried when I had that much butter left over, and I'm glad I did. This was easier then what I thought. Just give yourself sometime, and don't rush. I will be making this for years to come.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful recipe - I have made this for Greek and Arab friends, and all of them loved it, one even asked for the recipe. If that's not a sign of a great Baklava recipe, I don't know. :)
I've followed the tips of previous reviewers - 1,5 times the amount of sauce, let it cool, and cut almost to the bottom before you bake the baklava. I also use organic vanilla powder instead of liquid vanilla extract.
Since this has annoyed me several times now, and I always forget about it: Be sure to have a big/high enough saucepan - the sauce gets VERY frothy (>2 times the initial volume!) when it's simmering, and will spill over onto the stove if the saucepan is too small!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never made baklava before and was a little intimidated to work with the phyllo dough.  It wasn't as hard to work with as I thought.  The sheets of phyllo were the perfect size to lay in my 9 x 13 pan so I didn't need to cut them.  Also, I didn't need to keep them moist.  I found the dough was easier to work with not being moist.  (I did thaw my phyllo dough overnight in the refrigerator) and I did make the sauce ahead of time & let it cool in the refrigerator while I was preparing & baking the baklava.  Pouring the sauce directly over the hot baklava made it nice & crisp.  It was a little tricky getting it out of the pan, but it was absolutely delicious.  Even my husband who was turning his nose up at it while I was making it, tried it and liked it!  Now if I can just keep it until my son takes it in for his class project in 4 days.  I may need to make a 2nd batch!

I have never made baklava or used phyllo before so this was an experience. First 350 degrees was too high, my laers fell apart and I think because the phyllo was too dry and crisp so I think 325 would be better.  I felt there was not enough sauce and I did add a cinnamon stick and 3 whole cloves and a little orange peel to the sauce, but next time I would make 1 1/2 amount of sauce. Also a pound of nuts was too much, so I wouldonly use 3/4 lb crushed nuts, I used pecans, I also added some sugar...maybe 1/8 cup and a very little nutmeg and a little more orage peel.

text:
I was asked to make baklava by my husband's cousin and I was a little hesitant to make it since I hadn't done it before. Let me tell you, I will be making this again and again. If you work quickly enough with the phyllo dough, you don't have to cover it with a towel. Just make an assembly line and go for it. It took me about ten minutes to make two pans of baklava and get them in the oven. Not bad at all. I did make the syrup ahead of time and had it cooling on the counter to pour over the fresh from the oven baklava. Good luck and hope you enjoy making this wonderful dessert.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-01-31T13:29:38.583
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
3578288
Display Name:
ellie may
isPro:
False
followersCount:
50
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
52
favoritesCount:
228
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/187048.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this 5 star, and easier! Here is how: 1st! Make the SAUCE: 1-1/2 c. water, 1/2 c. white sugar, 1 cinnamon stick, 1/2 lemon; simmer for 20 min. Turn off heat, add 3/4 c. honey, 1 TBSP real vanilla, stir well, bottle and refrigerate. NUTS: 5 cups of toasted pecans and raw walnuts, chopped fine, add 1/4 tsp. ginger, nutmeg, clove and 1/8 tsp cardamom and 2 tsp. cinnamon. DOUGH: Athens 9x13 phyllo; thawed in frig. Bring to room temperature. Melt 1 stick butter in mug in microwave. Lay sheet of wax paper on counter, open 1st dough package, unroll dough, place 1 sheet on wax paper, blot with buttered silicone brush. Add sheet of dough, blot with butter brush, until you have a stack of 8 sheets. Remove to safe area, and continue to create stacks of 8 buttered dough sheets on wax paper, you will end up with 5 total stacks (will be a few sheets left over). Butter the 9X13 pan, lay a stack of sheets in bottom. Add 1/3 of nut mixture. Lay stack of 8 buttered sheets on top, add 1/3 nuts, another stack, last 1/3 of nuts, add last stack on top of pan. Butter leftover sheets of dough and add to top. Put in refrigerator for an hour. Preheat oven to 325. Remove pan from refrigerator, with sharp knife, cut into desired shapes, do NOT cut through to bottom of pan. Place on middle rack in oven, for 40 minutes, check often after 30 minutes, until golden brown. Remove from oven, immediately pour cold syrup over baklava, especially into cuts. Refrigerate before cutting through bottom. Enjoy!

5

I went to college with Greeks, live down the street from an amazing Greek pizza parlor and this is the good stuff. The only changes I've made are different nuts or some citrus zest r a hint of nutmeg. It could go for a lower temp or less time, just keep an eye on it. I normally make sure the nuts are nice and small, a spice grinder will help there.  I did make a different version for a wedding shower once. Added lime zest to the sauce and used crystallized ginger in the filling with almonds. Very different but good.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/174787.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a GREAT recipe! I don't think I'll ever go back to buying baklava again!    Like other reviewers, I lightly toasted the nuts.  I personally, really like the combination of pecans, walnuts and almonds. And, used only cinnamon to flavour the nuts.  Instead of making them in the 9 x 13 pan, I cut the dough into four even sections length wise.  Buttered one  strip.  Filled the corner of one strip with the nut mixture and folded the pieces into small triangles.  Then butter another strip, rewrapping the triangle. I cut three slits on the top and baked for about 30 minutes. This way makes a really crisp and flaky baklava. But, it is really time consuming. (to get a sense of how the triangles are made take a look at the cranberry phyllo triangle recipe on this site.)

Great recipe.... easy to make... made some minor changes to it.. I added pumpkin pie seasoning and cinnamon to the nut mix, I think next time I would grind the nuts because I found that chopped nuts are too chunky, I doubled the sauce amount because the amount the recipe calls for seemed like not enough and I highly recommend the use of plastic wrap over the phyllo dough prior to placing the damp cloth over the dough to avoid from the dough tearing..   I think next time I will use some middle eastern spices for an authentic taste per the recommendation of my mother in law.

text:
This recipe turned out well and was easier to make than I expected. I followed the reviewers' recommendations to make 50% extra sauce. I found it almost too sweet and rich, but I guess that's what baklava is! I also cooled the sauce before pouring it over, and I found that I used 50% more nuts as well, but maybe I was just putting too much on. If you're intimidated about making this, it's really not too hard, just a little time consuming. Give it a try.   I made these for a Greek class and they were a hit!

Like other viewers I had made this recipe for ages and I never look into the ratings and suggestions I have to say that it really help, I didn't know why my was soggy sometimes and now I learned that I need to add the syrup cold, also I did change the syrup a little bit by adding lemmon juice and substracting the vanilla, since I like a more lemony taste I also added the lemon peel to the syrup wile cooking and then I removed it and ready, also for the nut mix I added just a dash of ground cloves and nutmeg. this has allways been a hit in my household and with friend I make it every cristmas for my co-workers and even for y dad's co-workers I made it this year since they love it last year. this recipe is a keeper!!

userID:
2627653
Display Name:
AbbyMP
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/204027.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made two batches of this, and I was surprised at how easy it turned out to be.  I completely melted the butter and used a brush to smooth it on, this way the phyllo dough didn't tear.  The first batch seemed like it could have been just a little sweeter (it certainly wasn't bad, just could have been sweeter), so for the second batch I increased the cinnamon/sugar in each layer.  This caused it to be VERY sticky, and I wouldn't do this in the future.  Also, I noticed on my first batch that the pieces were very big.  I would make sure that when you cut this before you bake it, always cut the pieces just a little smaller than you think.  It is much harder to cut after it has been baked.  Both of these batches got great reviews, and I will definitely make it again!

text:
WOW! I never thought I could make baklava until now! This recipe was great and super easy.  The first time I made it I used one stick of extra butter like someone suggested and that batch turned out soooo gooey and sweet.  I made this another time but only used the recommended butter amount and it was not as gooey and was dry, even after letting it sit overnight.   You definitely don't want to skimp on the butter if you want that truly fantastic baklava look and taste!

text:
I looked this recipe up after having authentic baklava in Greece this summer. I wasn't expecting it to be this easy or delicious.  One tip- to "butter thoroughly" I melted the butter in the microwave and brushed it over the phyllo layers with a basting brush- it worked well and spread evenly without tearing. Excellent! Everyone went back for seconds!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read all of the tips and did make the sauce ahead of time. I added 2 t. of rosewater to the nut mixture to give it more Mideastern flavor. Unfortunately the phyllo sheets were just a tad too large for my pans and trimming after the fact was not good. So I definitely recommend that you check the phyllo to your pan to make sure it lies in nicely and trim, if necessary, BEFORE you start assembly.  I've also recently seen some baklava being sold with chocolate. So I took half the pan and drizzled melted chocolate just on the top. I think too much chocolate is overpowering.

userID:

Display Name:
Carol S
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used a new 2" bristle paint brush to apply the butter to the phyllo, doing two half sheets at a time; the remainder was covered with saran and a damp kitchen towel.  I made the sauce first so it would be cool when poured over the baklava.  I also tweaked the sauce recipe by adding a fresh vanilla bean, instead of extract; fishing it out after the sauce had cooled. I also added two teaspoons of fresh lemon juice at this point.  I only made one recipe of the sauce, which was sufficient.  My baklava was picture perfect (no wrinkles) and delicious!  It became my 33-year-old son's birthday cake.  Thanks for great recipe and helpful reviews.

text:
I originally made this baklava for a small banquet that I had volunteered to run. This was so easy that I was afraid it was too simple and would be missing a flavour or something and would disappoint those of us who've had baklava in the past. I was lucky that it was so easy (and that I followed the suggestion of others to add cool sauce to hot baklava) as I did not have a chance to test the recipe beforehand and I was cooking for nearly 40 guests. I heard nothing but the best compliments about this recipe from both guests who have never had baklava and those who specifically seek restaurants that serve "the best baklava you've ever tasted." I have since made several batches to give out in addition to cookies this holiday season. I feel will be hanging on to this recipe for a long, long time.

itsallsilly

text:
This recipe ROCKS!!  I tried it once as a test run before xmas and i didnt follow all of the advice and it turned out a little soggy, but 2nd time around I used the advice plus added layers and  made this for christmas with family and everyone LOVED it!  I didnt use a whole stick of butter to coat the dough and i used the lemon zest in the syrupy part.  I also followed the advice to pour cool syrup over hot baklava (i used extra syrup 1.5 times the recipe, but i also used more filling) i used ten layers of phyllo between the layers of filling and then fifteen or so on the top (I was shooting for 60 layers but at midnight after baking all day I just couldnt make it). Everyone thought I had slaved away to make gourmet baklava!!

text:
My husband asked me if I think I could make Baklava homemade. I scoffed, then came to AllRecipes. It was time consuming, but very easy! I followed the recipe exactly as written, and it came out wonderful. The only thing I had any problem with is cutting the Baklava before it went into the oven. I even used my super sharp Henkles, but some of the dough ripped. I'm sure cutting it is a skill I can master over time. I gave some to my neighbor, whose favorite dessert is Baklava. She said it was the best baklava she has ever had. Better than any restaurant - I am making more tomorrow, because it is already gone, and it is the talk of all my friends now! And my husband inhaled 4 piecesas soon as he saw them. I am so glad I gave this a try. Seriously perfect Baklava.

text:
Oh My!  This is wonderful! Yes it is time consuming but it is well worth it!  The only problem I had was cutting it it into diagonals as the top layer kept trying to come off, but no biggie I just tried to smooth it back out as well as I could. Some people said they thought there was much to honey sauce, I thought so at first, but it was quicly absorbed. Be sure to put it on immediately after pulling your Baklava from the oven, it is fun to watch it sizzle and then dissappear into the layers.  I let it sit over night and dug into it this morning. I have to say, it is better than any thing I have had at restaurants!  I had to give myself a pat on the back for this one!  Thanks for the wonderful recipe :-)

text:
My boyfriend pointed out a tray of baklava at the store the other day, and mentioned it would be a good Christmas present for him. However, the price and the amount of pieces in a single tray was crazy. So I went home and found this recipe and made it the next day (for much cheaper!). I doubled the sauce like the others suggested, but I didn't use all of it (but most of it). Being on a budget, I just grabbed a can of cheap mixed nuts.  It turned out a little more peanutity then most baklava I've had, but thats not a bad thing.  It's definitely one of my favorite desserts now!

text:
I've never made Baklava before, so I wasn't expecting it to be so easy. Time consuming, like woah, but easy. Also, for those that would prefer a thinner, not as over the top with the sweet, just use half of the phyllo dough. It makes for a thinner Baklava. You may want to adjust the recipe by half if you do that though. I still have the rest of the honey-sugar sauce waiting on some chicken in the fridge. =D

text:
Nice basic recipe. I omitted the vanilla and used rosewater and orange blossom water for a more middle eastern twist.  also added grated lemon zest to the syrup.  I like nuts toasted before I add them to anything for a better level of flavor and to avoid bitterness. Used a combo of cashews and almonds crushed finely and put them on a cookie sheet to toast in the oven while it was preheating.  I might want to make 1 and 1/2 times the syrup next time. One recipe didn't seem quite enough but doubling would be too much. thanks to the other reviewers for the invaluable tips.

userID:
795035
Display Name:
StewartFip
isPro:
False
followersCount:

3

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is amazing, I've used it for years.

I know it's not traditional, but I prefer a combination of almonds, pecans and walnuts in equal proportions; all unsalted, and chopped by hand with a knife.  Chopping by machine creates a great deal of flour that gums up later when applying the syrup.  Larger chunks of nuts lift up the phyllo and let the sauce get in between the layers.

Also, more butter isn't better in this case.  Butter contains water, and the dish will spend the better part of the time in the oven poaching instead of getting nice and crispy if you use too much.  I've made this mistake.  Spread the butter sparingly and use only what's called for in the recipe.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2007-07-10T07:23:15.04

This is a great recipe. The only problem I had was that I left my walnuts in the food processor too long, and they became moist (practically pureed!), which made them hard to sprinkle.  Still, it all turned out wonderfully.   Thanks for the recipe!!

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good.  Tastes as good or better than store-bought.  Only problem - the 2 to 3 tablespoons of nuts per layer must be very large, at least for the package of dough I used; probably more like 4 tablespoons per layer if you want to use all the nuts before you run out of dough.  I sprinkled the rest of the nuts over top after baking.  If you boil the syrup the whole 20 minutes it shouldn't be soggy, at least mine wasn't.  Used 200 grams hazelnuts, 100 grams peanuts, 100 grams almonds and 50 grams cashews.  Definitely worth trying!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy yummy. I had some Baklava at a Lebanese restaurant recently that was just sinful, so I thought I'd try my own. I only used half of the phyllo dough, half the nuts, and half the butter (margarine actually... and melted... spreads better), but I did 1.5 times the sauce. I substituted Splenda for sugar (which has worked for everything I've baked so far... including creme brulee). It was quite time consuming, especially because store-bought walnuts aren't very finely chopped. And it was my first time using Phyllo (I'm a big fan of puff pastry dough though), so that took some getting used to. All in all, it was very messy, but very yummy straight out of the oven. I hope that it will congeal a little more in the fridge overnight... we shall see!
